2. Their chief centre of political power lay at Korkai, a place famous for cotton trade.
3. King Karikala founded Puhar and constructed 160 km of embankment along the Kaveri River.
Which of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct
• During the Sangam period, the Chola kingdom, known as Cholamandalam, was positioned north-east
of the pandya and chera territory, lying between the Pennar and Velar rivers.
• Flourishing between 300 BCE and 300 CE, this early Chola era was characterized by its contribution to the
cultural and literary landscape of ancient South India.
• The Cholas during this time were patrons of Tamil literature and poetry, nurturing the growth of Sangam
literature.
• Their territory, with its strategic location, facilitated trade and cultural exchanges with neighboring regions, contributing to the kingdom's prosperity.
• Though less centralized than their imperial successors, the Sangam Cholas played a significant role in
shaping the political and cultural dynamics of their time.
Statement 2 is not correct
• In the early Chola period, the primary center of political authority was situated at Uraiyur, renowned for
its vibrant cotton trade.
• Flourishing between the 3rd century BCE and the 3rd century CE, Uraiyur served as a pivotal hub for
economic activity and governance.
• As the heart of the Chola kingdom, it facilitated trade networks and cultural exchanges, contributing to
the region's prosperity.
• Korkai was an important Pandya port famous for pearls.
Statement 3 is correct
• Renowned for his visionary leadership, King Karikala of the Chola dynasty left an indelible mark on ancient South India.
• Notably, he is credited with the foundation of the city of Puhar and the construction of an impressive
160-kilometer-long embankment along the Kaveri River.
• These monumental achievements not only enhanced the kingdom's infrastructure but also facilitated
agricultural development and trade along the fertile banks of the Kaveri.

questions.question: Who among the following is known as Red Chera or Good Chera?
questions.explanation:
The Chera Kingdom, one of the prominent dynasties of ancient South India, flourished during the Sangam Age, approximately from the 3rd century BCE to the 3rd century CE.
• According to Chera poets, the pinnacle of their kingdom's leadership was embodied in Senguttuvan,
famously known as the Red or Good Chera.
• Revered for his military prowess, he triumphed over his adversaries and ensured the stability of his
cousin's rule.
• Legends even attribute to him the audacious feat of invading northern territories and crossing the Ganges, though such claims likely carry elements of embellishment.
• By the second century, Chera influence waned, and historical records became sparse until the eighth
century, leaving a gap in our understanding of the kingdom's trajectory and governance during this period of decline.
• Cheras were known for their maritime trade connections with foreign lands, particularly the Roman
Empire, the Cheras established a prosperous economy based on trade in spices, precious stones, and
other commodities.
• Their capital, Vanji (present-day Karur), served as a hub for commercial activities and cultural exchange

questions.question: With reference to ancient India, Title of Enadi refers to?

options.text: The title of an Indian epic poem.

questions.explanation:
The warrior class was an important element in the polity and society.
• It is said in sangam texts that the Commanders of the army were invested with the title of Enadi at a
formal ceremony.
• The kshatriyas and vaishyas appear as regular varnas in the Sangam texts. However, we have no clear
idea about the vaishyas.
• According to sangam texts, civil and military offices were held under both the Cholas and Pandyas by
vellalas or rich peasants.
• The ruling class was called arasar, and its members had marriage relations with the vellalas, who formed
the fourth caste.
• Arasar held the bulk of the land and thus constituted the cultivating class, divided into the rich and the
poor.
• The rich did not plough the land themselves but employed labourers to undertake this.
• The vellalas held the bulk of land, and employed kadaisiyan (agricultural labour) to do the manual farm
work.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs regarding Sangam age:
 Empire Capital
1. Chola Vanji
2. Chera Uraiyur
3. Pandya Madurai
How many of the pair(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is not correct
• Chola:
 Initially, the capital of the Cholas was Uraiyur. Later it was shifted to Puhar (also called Poompuhar).
 The insignia/emblem of the Cholas was Tiger.
 King Karikala was a prominent king of the Sangam Chola dynasty.
Pair 2 is not correct
• Chera:
 Vanji was the capital of the Cheras.
 The emblem of Cheras is the bow and arrow.
 The first-century Pugalur inscriptions references 3 generations of Chera kings.
 Senguttuvan (2nd century CE) was the prominent ruler of the Chera dynasty.
 Musiri and Tondi were the important seaports in this period.
Pair 3 is correct
• Pandya:
 Madurai (center of trade and industry) was the capital of Pandyas.
 The Pandyas reigned over the Southern region of modern-day Tamil Nadu.
 Their emblem is Carp (Fish).
 King Neduncheliyan was the prominent king of this period.
 According to mythology, the curse of the Kannagi, wife of Kovalan, burnt and destroyed Madurai.
 The socio-economic condition of the seaport of Korkai was mentioned in Madurai Kanji which was
written by Mangudi Maruthanar.
 Pandyas had trade relations with Romans.
 Pandyas are mentioned in Kautilya‘s Arthashastra and Megasthenes‘ Indica.

questions.question:
Which one of the following is the correct chronological order (largest to smallest)
for the division of kingdom during Sangam age?
questions.explanation:
The kingdom was divided into Mandalam (Territory), Nadu (province), Ur (town), Perur (big village),
and Sirur (small village) for administrative convenience.
• These divisions facilitated the governance of the broader territories controlled by major kingdoms like
the Cholas, Cheras, and Pandyas.
• The system allowed for a hierarchical structure of governance, enabling efficient administration, taxation,
and defense throughout the kingdom.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Rigvedic age:
1. Cattle were considered to be synonymous with wealth, and a wealthy person was called gopa or
gomati.
2. Wars were fought over cattle and, therefore, the raja, whose principal responsibility was to protect
the cows, was called gomat.
Which of the statement(s) given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct
• Written texts provide invaluable insights into societal evolution from the Rig Veda era onwards.
• The Rig Vedic society, although proficient in agriculture, predominantly revolved around pastoralism.
• Semi-nomadic lifestyles were prevalent, with cattle and horses being the primary assets.
• This pastoral emphasis is evident in the Rig Vedic texts, where terms like cow, bull, and horse are recurrently mentioned.
• Cattle, in particular, were regarded as symbols of wealth, to the extent that a wealthy individual was
termed "gomat."
• While agriculture held importance, the centrality of pastoralism indicates a nomadic lifestyle that prioritized the management and accumulation of cattle and horses.
• This emphasis on pastoral wealth reflects not only the economic foundation of society but also its cultural
and social values.
Statement 2 is not correct
• Cattle held such paramount importance in ancient Vedic society that wars were waged over their possession.
• Consequently, the ruler, whose foremost duty was the protection of these valuable assets, was bestowed
with titles like gopa or gopati.
• The cow's centrality to sustenance was profound, to the extent that familial roles were defined in relation
to it, with daughters being termed duhitr, meaning "one who milks."
• This close association with cattle is evidenced by the Vedic people's intimate knowledge, as illustrated by
their reference to the buffalo as govala, or cow-haired, upon encountering it in India.
• The prominence of cattle in Vedic society is further underscored by the scarcity of agricultural references
in the earlier hymns of the Rig Veda, with cattle-rearing emerging as the primary livelihood for the populace.
• This reliance on cattle rearing not only shaped economic practices but also influenced social structures
and cultural norms within Vedic society.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Economic relation of Sangam age:
1. The Handicraft during sangam included weaving, metal works and carpentry, ship building and making of ornaments using beads, stones and ivory.
2. Handicrafts were in great demand in the internal and external trade that was at its peak during the
Sangam period.
3. A high expertise was attained in spinning and weaving of cotton and silk clothes.
How many of the above statement(s) is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Handicrafts during the Sangam period encompassed a diverse array of skilled crafts, ranging from
weaving and metalwork to carpentry, shipbuilding, and the creation of intricate ornaments.
• Weavers produced finely crafted textiles, while artisans demonstrated expertise in metalwork, crafting
objects of utility and adornment.
• Carpentry skills were employed in the construction of structures and furniture.
• Notably, shipbuilding flourished, facilitating maritime trade and exploration.
• Additionally, artisans displayed mastery in ornamentation, fashioning jewelry using beads, stones, and
ivory, showcasing the sophistication and artistic prowess of Sangam-era craftsmanship across various
domains.
Statement 2 is correct
• Handicrafts held significant importance during the Sangam period, as evidenced by their high demand
in both internal and external trade networks, which flourished during this era.
• Skilled artisans produced a wide range of crafted goods, including textiles, metalwork, ceramics, and
jewelry, which were sought after not only within the local economy but also in international markets.
• The thriving trade routes facilitated the exchange of these handicrafts across regions, contributing to
economic prosperity and cultural exchange.
• This demand for handicrafts in trade underscored their integral role in the economy of the Sangam period, reflecting the sophistication and value placed on artisanal craftsmanship during this vibrant period
of South Indian history.
Statement 3 is correct
• During the historical period, significant advancements were made in the spinning and weaving of both
cotton and silk fabrics, leading to a high level of expertise in these textile crafts.
• Skilled artisans mastered intricate techniques, resulting in the production of finely woven textiles renowned for their quality and craftsmanship.
• Cotton and silk fabrics became highly sought after commodities, prized for their luxurious feel, vibrant
colors, and intricate designs.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. Tamil people were primarily hunters and traces of early megalithic life appear in the Sangam texts.
2. Ancient primitive tribes like Thodas, Irulas, Nagas and Vedars lived in this period.
3. Courage, creativity and spirituality of women was respected in Sangam society.
4. Royal courts were filled with singing bards known as Panar and Viraliyar.
How many of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is not correct
• The Sangam texts offer glimpses into the early lifestyle of Tamil people, revealing a predominantly
pastoral society intertwined with traces of early megalithic life.
• These texts portray the Tamil people's close relationship with pastoralism, highlighting their reliance on
cattle herding as a primary means of livelihood.
• Cattle were esteemed symbols of wealth and played a central role in their economy and social structure.
• Traces of early megalithic life appear in the Sangam texts.
 Megalithic life: This refers to a prehistoric period characterized by the construction of large stone
monuments for burials or rituals.
Statement 2 is correct
• During the ancient period, primitive tribes such as the Thodas, Irulas, Nagas, and Vedars inhabited the
region.
• These tribes, often referred to as indigenous or aboriginal, lived in close connection with the natural
environment, relying on hunting, gathering, and simple agricultural practices for sustenance.
• Their lifestyles were characterized by a deep understanding of local ecosystems and resource utilization.
• The Thodas, for instance, were known for their expertise in shifting cultivation and their semi-nomadic
lifestyle in the Nilgiri Hills.
• Similarly, the Irulas were skilled hunters and gatherers, while the Nagas and Vedars inhabited forested
regions, often engaging in activities like hunting, gathering forest produce, and small-scale agriculture.
Statement 3 is correct
• In Sangam society, women were esteemed for their courage, creativity, and spirituality, marking a
departure from the patriarchal norms prevalent in many ancient societies.
• Women were celebrated for their bravery in battles and their ability to contribute to various aspects of
society beyond domestic roles.
• Sangam literature depicts women as poets, scholars, and leaders, showcasing their intellectual and creative capabilities.
• Additionally, spirituality held a central place in Sangam society, and women were revered for their devotion to religious practices and their roles as custodians of family and community rituals.
Statement 4 is correct
• During the Sangam Age, royal courts were vibrant centers of cultural patronage and entertainment,
often filled with singing bards known as Panar and Viraliyar.
• These bards played a crucial role in the courtly life, entertaining the royalty and the aristocracy with their
musical performances and recitations of epic poetry and heroic tales.
• The Panars specialized in singing praise songs and composing poetry celebrating the valor and achievements of the rulers and their lineage, while the Viraliyars were known for their poignant and emotive
renditions of love songs and lyrical poetry.
• Their performances not only entertained but also served to glorify the rulers and reinforce their legitimacy
and power.
• Additionally, the presence of these bards added to the cultural richness and sophistication of the royal
courts, making them vibrant hubs of artistic expression and literary creativity during the Sangam period.

questions.question: With reference to the Sangam period, the term ‘Umnar’ refers to:
questions.explanation:
Option 1 is not correct
• The ‘Vetar’ were considered to be hunter-gatherers and are often associated with the forest and mountain regions.
• They are depicted in Sangam literature as a group that lived in harmony with nature, engaged in hunting,
gathering, and sometimes shifting cultivation.
• Their lifestyle and social status were distinct from those of the agrarian and urban populations.
• Sangam literature often portrays the Vetar in a romanticised manner, highlighting their knowledge of
the wilderness and their skills in hunting.
Option 2 is not correct
• At the core of the agrarian landscape, the ‘Ulavar’ were the principal plough agriculturists.
• Their duties encompassed a spectrum of agricultural activities, including ploughing fields, sowing seeds,
nurturing crops, and reaping harvests.
• While rice stood as the primary crop, they also diversified their cultivation to include millets, sugarcane,
and pulses. with tools like ploughs, hoes, and sickles, the ‘Ulavar’ tilled the land with precision and skill.
Option 3 is correct
• The ‘Umnar’ were esteemed as the salt manufacturers, a community whose significance transcended
mere trade to become integral to the economic and social fabric of ancient Tamilakam.
• This era, renowned for its flourishing Tamil literature and diverse cultural tapestry, saw salt as a precious
commodity, essential for both sustenance and preservation.
• The Umnar, through their specialised knowledge and skilled craftsmanship, played a pivotal role in the
production and distribution of salt, ensuring its availability across the region.
• They extracted salt from saline-rich coastal areas, marshlands, and inland salt pans, employing traditional
techniques passed down through generations.
Option 4 is not correct
• The ‘Idaiyar’ held a distinguished role as cattle-keepers, contributing significantly to the economic and
social landscape of ancient Tamilakam.
• The Idaiyar, through their intimate knowledge of cattle husbandry and astute stewardship, played a pivotal role in the rearing, breeding, and utilisation of livestock.

questions.question:
With reference to the Sangam authorities, consider the following pairs:
 Ministers Portfolios
1. Kanakasurram Treasury officials
2. Kadaikappalar Palace guards
3. Karanattiyalavar Accountants
4. Karumakarar Executive officials
How many of the above pairs(s) is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is correct
• During the Sangam period, ‘Kanakasurram’ referred to the treasury officials who were pivotal in managing the financial resources of the ancient Tamil kingdoms.
• Their roles encompassed the collection, safeguarding, and disbursement of state revenues, ensuring the
economic stability and prosperity of the region.
Pair 2 is correct
• The ‘Kadaikappalar’, often referred to as palace guards, played a significant role in the Sangam era of
Tamil history.
• The primary duty of the Kadaikappalar was to ensure the safety and security of the king, the royal family,
and the palace premises.
• This involved not only guarding the palace gates but also maintaining vigilance within the palace grounds
to prevent any internal threats. Their presence was crucial for the protection of the royal household from
both external and internal dangers.
Pair 3 is correct
• The ‘Karanattiyalavar’, or accountants, were an integral part of the administrative machinery during the
Sangam era.
• The primary responsibility of the Karanattiyalavar was to maintain accurate records of the kingdom’s
finances.
• In addition to managing financial records, the Karanattiyalavar were involved in overseeing land transactions and the collection of agricultural taxes, which were significant sources of revenue.
Pair 4 is correct
• The ‘Karumakarar’ which refers to executive officials, were essential to the administrative structure of
the Sangam era (300 BCE -300 CE).
• Their primary duty was to implement the king's directives, ensuring efficient governance across the
kingdom.
• They coordinated with various departments, managed resources, and oversaw lower-level officials to
maintain the smooth operation of the state.

questions.question: With reference to the Sangam period, the terms ‘Iravu’ and ‘Karai’ refer to:
questions.explanation:
The term "Iravu" referred to a forced gift or an extra demand imposed by those in power, typically
the ruling elite or officials representing the state. This term denotes a form of extraction beyond regular
taxes or dues.
• The "Iravu" could take various forms, such as additional tribute demanded from subjects, requisition of
goods or services without compensation, or even forced labour.
• "Karai" specifically refers to land tax. This term denotes the levy imposed on agricultural land by the
ruling authority.
• It was often based on the fertility and productivity of the land, with assessments made by officials appointed for this purpose

questions.question:
With reference to the “Tolkappiyam”, consider the following pairs:
 Land type Chief deity
1. Kurinji Murugan
2. Marudam Indra
3. Neydal Varunan
4. Palai Korravai
How many of the above Pair(s) is/are not correct?
questions.explanation:
The society during Sangam was characterised by a well-defined social structure and, to some extent,
gender equality.
• The society was organised into different strata, or divisions, based on occupation and land.
• Tolkappiyam refers to a five-fold division of lands: Kurinji, Marudam, Neydal, Palai, and Mullai.
Pair 1 is correct
• The region of Kurinji, characterised by its hilly tracks, is categorised as one of the five types of landscapes.
• The chief deity associated with Kurinji was Lord Murugan, also known as Subramanya or Kartikeya. Murugan was revered as the god of war, victory, and wisdom in Tamil culture.
• His connection to Kurinji reflects the spiritual significance attributed to the region's rugged and untamed
landscapes.
• The primary occupation of the inhabitants of Kurinji was hunting and honey collection. The hilly terrain
provided abundant opportunities for hunting wild animals and gathering honey from natural beehives
nestled within the rocky outcrops. These activities were essential for sustenance and livelihood in the
region.
• The inhabitants of Kurinji were primarily Kurvar and Vetar.
• Kurvars were a community traditionally associated with hunting and gathering, while the Vetars were
known for their expertise in honey collection and beekeeping.
Pair 2 is correct
• Marudam was distinguished by its fertile plains, which were suitable for agriculture and cultivation. It
represented the agrarian landscape, where farming and cultivation activities predominated.
• The chief deity associated with Marudam was Indra, also known as the rain god or the deity of fertility
and prosperity.
• The primary inhabitants of Marudam were Ayar and Idaiyar. These communities were traditionally associated with agriculture and were responsible for tilling the land, sowing seeds, and harvesting crops.
Pair 3 is correct
• Neydal was one of the five landscapes distinguished by its coastal features and maritime environment.
• The coastline offered a unique set of resources and economic opportunities.
• The chief deity associated with Neydal was Varunan, the god of the sea.
• Fishing and salt manufacturing were the chief occupations of the inhabitants of Neydal.
• The coastal environment provided abundant marine resources, including fish, shellfish, and seaweed,
which formed the basis of the coastal economy.
• Vellalar, belonging to the agricultural community, was also prominent in coastal regions, engaging
in farming activities adapted to the coastal environment, such as salt cultivation and cultivating saltresistant crops.
Pair 4 is correct
• Palai was one of the five landscapes distinguished by its arid conditions, scarcity of water, and limited
vegetation.
• The desert landscape posed significant challenges for habitation and sustenance.
• The chief deity associated with Palai was Korravai, a goddess often depicted as a warrior deity associated
with protection.
• Robbery was one of the chief occupations associated with Palai in Sangam literature.
• The primary inhabitants of Palai were Paratavar and Valayar. These communities were traditionally associated with a nomadic or semi-nomadic lifestyle, adapting to the harsh conditions of the desert.

questions.question: With reference to the Megalithic age the ‘Cists’ refer to:
questions.explanation:
A Cist is a small stone-built coffin-like box or ossuary used to hold the bodies of the dead.
• These types of burials were completely underground.
• They are typically constructed using stone, often with large slabs forming the walls and a cover slab or
capstone forming the roof.
• Cists can have a single chamber, designed to hold the remains of one individual, or they may have
multiple chambers for accommodating several individuals or for secondary burials.
• The top of the cist is often covered with a large stone slab, providing protection for the remains inside.
• Archaeologists often find artefacts, such as pottery, tools, or personal items, buried alongside the human
remains within the cist. These artefacts can provide clues about the culture and beliefs of the people who
created the cist.
• Cists are often found in association with other megalithic structures, such as dolmens, cairns, or stone
circles, within burial complexes or necropolises.

questions.question: Which term was denoted “customs duties” in the Sangam period?
questions.explanation:
Option (a) is correct
• In Sangam Tamil literature, there was a customary practice to collect a toll called”ulgu” from the traders,
which stands for customs duty.
• The commodities that were taxable were called ulgu-porul.
Option (c) is not correct
• Three levels of rulers are found in the Sangam period:
 Kizhar: They were the heads of the villages or a small territory, later known as Nadu. They were the
chiefs of tribal communities living in specific areas.
 Velir: They were many in number, controlling the territories of varied geographical nature, mainly
hilly and forest areas, that were in between the muvendar’s fertile territories.
Option (b) is not correct
 Vendar: They were kings controlling larger, fertile territories.
Option (d) is not correct
• Tyndis and Muzris (an ancient seaport on the Malabar Coast) were port cities of the Chera dynasties
in the Sangam period.
• The port thrived during the golden age of the historic Spice Route.
• The references by Ptolemy and the book “THE PERIPLUS OF THE ERYTHREAN SEA” also mention the
location of these coastal towns.
• Tyndis Port is regarded as the ancestor of the present-day Ponnani Port by the majority of historians.

questions.question: With reference to the Megalithic period, “Topikal” and “Dolmen” were used:

options.text: To act as a tool for trade

questions.explanation:
Topikal was used to mark the burial sites of Megalithic people. It was widely seen in Kerala and Tamil
Nadu.
• Characteristics of Topikal structures:
 Three Vertically Placed Stones: These stones are positioned upright in such a way that they form
the main structure of the topikal. They are arranged in a triangular formation, with each stone inclined
inwardly at the top.
 Inward Inclination: The inward inclination at the top of the vertical stones suggests that the stones
are not completely parallel but instead lean towards each other. This creates a stable base for the
cap stone and ensures that the structure is sturdy.
 Plano-Convex Cap Stone: A plano-convex stone is one that is flat on one side and convex (curved
outward) on the other. This cap stone is placed on top of the three vertical stones. The flat side
likely rests on the tips of the vertical stones, while the convex side faces upwards.A dolmen is a type of megalithic structure typically associated with prehistoric burial practices.
• It is characterized by a large flat capstone that is placed horizontally atop two or more upright stones,
creating a chamber beneath it.
• This chamber can sometimes be closed on three sides, forming a more enclosed space.
• Dolmens are often found in Europe, Asia, and Africa, and they were usually used as tombs or burial
chambers, signifying their importance in ancient rituals and practices related to death and the afterlife.
• Key characteristics of dolmens include:
 Capstone: A large, flat stone placed horizontally.
 Support Stones: Upright stones that hold up the capstone, forming the walls of the chamber.
 Chamber: The space beneath the capstone, sometimes enclosed on three sides,is used for burials

questions.question:
With reference to the Mahasabhas in Sangam period, consider the following
pairs:
 Mahasabhas Denotes
1. Amaichar Priests
2. Anthanar Ministers
3. Thuthar Envoys
4. Senapathi Military leaders
How many of the above pair(s) is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
In Sangam administration, the king served as the epicentre and personification of government.
• The King was aided by a vast number of administrators, who were organised into five groups:
• They were ministers (amaichar), priests (anthanar), military commanders (senapathi), envoys
(thuthar) and spies (orrar)
Pair 1 is not correct
• The Amaichar were important ministers during the Sangam period in ancient Tamil Nadu.
• Their responsibilities included advising the king, administering justice, and overseeing various aspects of
the kingdom's internal and external affairs.
Pair 2 is not correct
• During the Sangam period, the Anthanar held revered positions as priests who bridged the gap between
people and gods.
• They conducted rituals for prosperity and protection, advised rulers on matters of governance and morality, and preserved sacred knowledge.
Pair 3 is correct
• Thuthar refers to envoys or messengers during the Sangam period.
• They played crucial roles in communication, diplomacy, and maintaining relations between different kingdoms, chieftains, or allied groups.
Pair 4 is correct
• Senapathi refers to a military commander or general in ancient India, including during the Sangam
period.
• During the Sangam period, the Senapathi held a prominent position in the military hierarchy of the
Tamil kingdoms.
• They were responsible for leading and organising the army, strategizing military campaigns, and ensuring
the defence of the kingdom against external threats.

questions.question: The period from c.750−1000 CE was marked by the ‘tripartite struggle’ among three political powers in northern India. Which among the following was NOT involved in the ‘tripartite struggle’?
questions.explanation: The tripartite struggle was between the Gurjara-Pratiharas, the Palas, and the Rashtrakutas for control of the Kannauj region. The Pallavas, a South Indian dynasty, were not part of this conflict.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs of Kings and their respective Dynasties:
1. Rajendra I - The Rashtrakutas
2. Dharmapala - The Palas
3. Nagabhatta I - The Pratihara
4. Vatsaraja - The Pallavas
Which of the above are correctly matched?
questions.explanation: Rajendra I belonged to the Chola dynasty, not the Rashtrakutas. Dharmapala was a ruler of the Pala dynasty. Nagabhatta I was a ruler of the Gurjara Pratiharas. Vatsaraja also belonged to the Pratiharas, not the Pallavas. So, only pairs 2 and 3 are correctly matched.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the Pratiharas:
1) The real founder of the Pratihara empire and the greatest ruler of the dynasty was Bhoja I.
2) Al-Masudi, an Arab traveller, visited the Pratihara empire.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Bhoja I (Mihir Bhoja) was the greatest ruler of the Pratihara dynasty and established its dominance. Al-Masudi, an Arab traveler, visited the Pratihara empire in 915-916 CE and described its vastness and power.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the Rashtrakuta Dynasty:
1. The kingdom was founded by Krishna I, who set up his capital at Manyakhet.
2. Amoghavarsha I of Rashtrakuta authored the Prashnottara Ratnamalika in Kannada language.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: The Rashtrakuta kingdom was founded by Dantidurga, not Krishna I. Amoghavarsha I authored Prashnottara Ratnamalika in Sanskrit, not Kannada.

questions.question: Which of the following is not correct with respect to the Palas of Bengal?

options.text: The Pala kings were the followers of Jainism.
The Pala empire was founded by Gopala.
The Pala period is considered one of the golden eras in the history of Bengal.
The Palas power was destroyed by the Sena dynasty.

questions.explanation: The Pala kings followed Buddhism, particularly Mahayana and Tantric schools, not Jainism. The Pala Empire was founded by Gopala and was considered a golden era in Bengal's history. The Sena dynasty ultimately destroyed Pala power.

questions.question: Which empire was called “Ruhimi or Ruhma Dharma’’ by the Arab merchant Sulaiman?
questions.explanation: The 9th-century Arab merchant Sulaiman referred to the Pala Empire as "Ruhimi or Ruhma Dharma." He noted that the Pala emperor was at war with the Pratiharas and Rashtrakutas and had a large army. His writings highlight the Pala Empire’s flourishing Buddhist culture and vibrant trade networks.

questions.question:
With reference to the Chola dynasty (c. 850-1200 CE), how many of the given statements are not correct?
1. The Chola inscriptions generally refer to the king as Perumal.
2. Chola kings were majorly patrons of the Vaishnava Cult.
3. The Uttaramerur Inscription is related to the Chola dynasty.
questions.explanation:
Statements 1 and 3 are correct: The Chola inscriptions refer to the king as Perumal along with other titles like ko, rajarajadhiraja, etc. The Uttaramerur Inscription testifies to the Chola system of local self-governance.
Statement 2 is incorrect: The Cholas were primarily Shaivites, not Vaishnavites. They made significant contributions to Shaivite temple architecture and bronze sculptures, particularly the famous Nataraja (Shiva as the cosmic dancer) statues.

questions.question: Arrange the following Chola Kings chronologically: 1) Rajadhiraja 2) Vijayalaya 3) Parantaka I 4) Rajendra I
questions.explanation: The correct chronological order is Vijayalaya (850 CE), Parantaka I (907-953 CE), Rajendra I (1014-1044 CE), Rajadhiraja (1044-1052 CE). Vijayalaya founded the Chola empire. Parantaka I expanded it. Rajendra I continued expansion, and Rajadhiraja was a great warrior.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the trade guilds during the period 800 CE to 1200 CE: 1) Statement-I: In north India, trade guilds or shrenis and sanghs prospered during this period. 2) Statement-II: The long-distance trade declined in north India during this period.

options.text: a) Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is the correct explanation for Statement-I.
b) Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is not the correct explanation for Statement-I.
c) Statement-I is correct but Statement-II is incorrect.
d) Statement-I is incorrect but Statement-II is correct.

questions.explanation: Statement-I is incorrect, and Statement-II is correct. Long-distance trade declined in north India, leading to the decline of trade guilds. Guilds lost their importance, and some older shrenis evolved into sub-castes.

questions.question: The term ‘Canton’ or ‘Kanfu’ in early medieval history refers to:

options.text: a) Main seaport for foreign trade in China.
b) Famous guilds in India during that time.
c) A Grass mentioned in Dharmashastras beyond which travel is banned.
d) A wild vegetable of bitter taste ordinary people used

questions.explanation: Canton (Kanfu) was the main seaport for foreign trade in China, especially for Indian, Persian, and Arabian merchants. Indian monks also traveled to China via this route.

questions.question: Consider the following pairs: Medieval Name: 1) Kataha, 2) Suvarnadvipa, 3) Jambudvipa. Modern Name: Bengal, Indonesia, India. Which of the pairs given above are correct?
questions.explanation: Pair 2 (Suvarnadvipa = Indonesia) and Pair 3 (Jambudvipa = India) are correct. Pair 1 is incorrect; Kataha refers to Kedah (Malaya), not Bengal.

questions.question: What is meant by the term ‘bhoga’ or ‘fief’ in medieval Indian history?
questions.explanation: ‘Bhoga’ or ‘fief’ refers to revenue assignment granted by the state to officials or religious institutions. These were typically temporary and could be resumed by the ruler, but in practice, many became hereditary over time.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the early medieval society of India: 1. Chandals were required to hit a wooden board on a stick as they walked so that upper-caste people would not come into contact with them. 2. A female slave bearing a child to his master can get freedom in those times. 3. The marriageable age for girls increased, thus giving them opportunities for higher education. How many of the above statement(s) is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Statement 1 and 2 are correct: Chandals had to announce their presence to avoid contact with upper castes, and female slaves could gain freedom by bearing a child to their master. Statement 3 is incorrect as the marriageable age for girls decreased, hindering their educational opportunities.

questions.question: With reference to Indian Science in early medieval India, consider the following statements: 1. The growth of science in the country sped up during this period. 2. The surgery declined because the dissection of dead bodies was regarded as fit only for people of low castes. Which of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect as the growth of science slowed during this period due to societal stagnation and religious orthodoxy. Statement 2 is correct; surgery declined as dissection was considered a profession for low castes, and other scientific fields like astronomy were overshadowed by astrology.

questions.question: With reference to Mughal Architecture, consider the following statements: 1. Fatehpur Sikri, built by Akbar, contains a large artificial lake and Panch Mahal, which contains Buddhist temple elements. 2. Buland Darwaza, made by Akbar stands as the gateway of the Qutb complex in Delhi. Which of the statement(s) given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is correct: Fatehpur Sikri includes a large artificial lake and the Panch Mahal with Buddhist temple elements. Statement 2 is incorrect because the Buland Darwaza is at Fatehpur Sikri, not the Qutb complex in Delhi, which has Alai Darwaza.

questions.question: Who among the following supervised the translation of Mahabharata during the reign of Akbar?
questions.explanation: Abul Faizi supervised the translation of Mahabharata into Persian during Akbar's reign. He was a prominent scholar and poet, and brother to Abul Fazl, another key figure at Akbar's court.

questions.question: The Vijayanagar Empire was founded by the brothers Harihara and Bukka. Which of the following dynasties do they belong to?
questions.explanation: Harihara and Bukka were from the Sangama dynasty, which founded the Vijayanagara Empire. They played a key role in establishing and expanding the empire.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the rulers of the Vijayanagara Empire: 1. Proudhadevaraya or Devaraya II was titled Gajabetekara. 2. Krishna Devaraya was called Yavanarjya Prathishtapanacharya. 3. Vira Vijaya Bukka Raya was given the title of Andhra Pitamaha. How many of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Statement 1 and 2 are correct. Statement 3 is incorrect as the title “Andhra Pitamaha” was given to Krishna Devaraya.

questions.question: Which one of the following literary works was authored by Krishnadevaraya?
questions.explanation: Krishnadevaraya authored “Jambavati Kalyanam” in Telugu.

questions.question: The Vijayanagara Empire's capital, Hampi, was located near which of the following rivers?
questions.explanation: Hampi, the capital of the Vijayanagara Empire, was located near the Tungabhadra River in Karnataka.

questions.question: Who among the following was not one of the Ashtadiggajas during Krishnadevaraya's reign?
questions.explanation: Chand Bardai was a 12th-century poet, not one of the Ashtadiggajas during Krishnadevaraya’s reign.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Bahmani Kingdom: 1. Alauddin Hasan was the founder of the kingdom in 1347. 2. Vijayanagara rulers and the Bahmani sultans clashed for the areas in the Tungabhadra doab, the Krishna-Godavari delta, and in the Marathwada country. Which of the statement(s) given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation: Both statements 1 and 2 are correct. Alauddin Hasan was the founder of the Bahmani kingdom in 1347, and the Vijayanagara rulers and Bahmani sultans did clash over the mentioned regions.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Vijayanagara Empire: 1. Harihara II followed the policy of expansion towards the eastern sea coast. 2. Harihara II was able to maintain his position against the Bahmani and Warangal kingdoms. 3. Deva Raya I was defeated by Firuz Shah and paid ten lakhs of huns, pearls, and elephants as an indemnity. How many of the statement(s) above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation: All three statements are correct. Harihara II expanded towards the eastern coast, maintained his position against Bahmani and Warangal, and Deva Raya I was defeated and paid indemnity to Firuz Shah.

questions.question: The Thanjavur Brihadeshwara Temple was designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1987. Which of these is the correct name of the World Heritage Site that includes the temple?

options.text: b) Group of Monuments at Pattadakal
c) Group of Monuments at Mahabalipuram

questions.explanation: The Brihadisvara Temple in Thanjavur is part of the Great Living Chola Temples, a UNESCO World Heritage Site inscribed in 1987.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Bhakti movement in medieval India: 1. The Alvars' devotional hymns and poems were collected in the Naalayira Divya Prabandham and were devoted to Shiva. 2. The Nayanars' hymns and poems were collected in the Thirumurai and it was written in Sanskrit. Which of the statements given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation: Both statements are incorrect. The Alvars were devoted to Lord Vishnu, not Shiva, and their hymns were in Tamil. The Nayanars' hymns were in Tamil as well, not Sanskrit.

questions.question: With reference to the civilisation in Assam during the 6th century, consider the following statements: 1. The Kamarupa kings adopted the title Varman, which means armour and symbolises a warrior. 2. The formation of a Varna society and the growth of Buddhism and Brahmanism in the form of Shaivism and Vaishnavism were witnessed in this area. Which of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Kamarupa kings adopted the title 'Varman' meaning 'armour,' symbolizing a warrior. The area saw the growth of a Varna society, Buddhism, and Brahmanism, including Shaivism and Vaishnavism, in the 5th-6th centuries.

questions.question: Which one of the following was the first Turk who invaded India?
questions.explanation: Mahmud Ghazni was the first Turkish invader of India. He raided India multiple times from 971 to 1030 AD, including the famous sacking of the Somnath temple in 1025 AD.

questions.question: With reference to the Rajput states, consider the following pairs: Dynasty - Location 1. Gahadavals - Kannauj 2. Paramaras - Malwa 3. Chandellas - Bundelkhand 4. Tomars - Delhi How many of the pair(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: All pairs are correct. Gahadavals ruled Kannauj, Paramaras ruled Malwa, Chandellas ruled Bundelkhand, and Tomars ruled Delhi.

questions.question: With reference to the Rajput dynasty, consider the following statements: 1. Bhimdev I, the Solanki ruler, built the Sun Temple at Modhera. 2. Prithviraj Chauhan was defeated by Mahmood Ghazni in the first battle of Tarain. 3. Maha Rana Udai Singh of the Sisodia dynasty founded Udaipur city. How many of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Statement 1 and 3 are correct. Bhimdev I built the Sun Temple at Modhera, and Udai Singh founded Udaipur. Prithviraj Chauhan was not defeated by Mahmud Ghazni but by Muhammad Ghori.

questions.question: With reference to the Rajput kingdom, consider the following statements: 1. The term Suryavanshi, “House of Sun”, was considered as descended from Lord Ram. 2. The term Chandravanshi, “House of Moon” was considered as descended from Lord Krishna. Which of the statement(s) given above is/are not correct?
questions.explanation: Both statements are correct. Suryavanshi Rajputs are believed to descend from Lord Ram, and Chandravanshi Rajputs from Lord Krishna.

questions.question: Consider the following pairs: 1. Rajatarangini - Jayadeva 2. Gita Govindam - Kalhana 3. Prithviraj Raso - Chand Bardai 4. Katha Saritsagar - Somadeva How many of the pair(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Pair 1 and Pair 2 are incorrect. Rajatarangini was written by Kalhana, and Gita Govindam was composed by Jayadeva.

questions.question: Consider the following statements: 1. Mughal painting reached its climax under Akbar. 2. Under Jahangir, European painting was introduced at the court by the Portuguese priests. 3. Mosque-building reached its climax under Shah Jahan. Which of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Statement 1 and 2 are incorrect. Mughal painting reached its zenith under Jahangir, and European painting was introduced by Portuguese priests during Akbar's reign. Statement 3 is correct as mosque-building reached its peak under Shah Jahan with notable mosques like Jama Masjid.

questions.question: Consider the following pairs: 1. Tuzuk-i-Baburi - Babur 2. Humayun Nama - Gulbadan Begum 3. Akbar Nama - Abul Fazl 4. Muntakhab-ul-Tawarikh - Badauni How many of the pair(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: All the pairs are correct. The "Tuzuk-i-Baburi" was written by Babur, "Humayun Nama" by Gulbadan Begum, "Akbar Nama" by Abul Fazl, and "Muntakhab-ul-Tawarikh" by Al-Badaoni.

questions.question: In the context of Mughal India, for what are Daswant, Baswan, and Mansur renowned?
questions.explanation: Daswant, Baswan, and Mansur are renowned as painters during the Mughal era, especially under Akbar's patronage.

questions.question: With reference to Chola Empire, consider the following statements: 1. The Arabian Sea came to be known as the ‘Chola Lake.’ 2. Kamban, who wrote Ramayana in Tamil, was in the court of Cholas. 3. The Uttaramerur inscription gives information about the Local Self Government. How many of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect, as the Bay of Bengal was known as 'Chola Lake.' Statements 2 and 3 are correct: Kamban was in the Chola court, and the Uttaramerur inscription provides details about local self-governance.

questions.question: Consider the following pairs: King - Title/Known for 1. Vijayalaya - Founder of the Imperial Cholas 2. Rajendra I - Maduraikonda Chola 3. Parantaka I - Gangaikondachola How many of the above pair(s) is/are not correctly matched?
questions.explanation: Pair 1 is correct. Pair 2 is incorrect as Rajendra I was known as Gangaikondachola, not Maduraikonda Chola. Pair 3 is also incorrect as Parantaka I was not associated with the title Gangaikondachola.

questions.question: Consider the following Heritage Sites: 1. Shore Temple 2. Brihadeeswara Temple at Thanjavur 3. Kailashnath Temple at Kanchi. How many of the above is/are built by the Imperial Cholas?
questions.explanation: The Shore Temple is built by the Pallavas, Brihadeeswara Temple is built by the Cholas, and Kailashnath Temple is built by the Pallavas.

questions.question: Imperial Cholas were the feudatories of which among the following dynasties?
questions.explanation: The Cholas were initially feudatories of the Pallava dynasty before establishing their own empire.

questions.question: ‘Idangai’ and ‘Valangai’ in Chola empire is related to which among the following?
questions.explanation: 'Idangai' and 'Valangai' were caste groupings in Chola society, with 'Idangai' being artisans and traders, and 'Valangai' being agricultural groups.

questions.question: Consider the following dynasties: 1. The Pandyas 2. The Cheras 3. The Chalukyas 4. The Lambakannas How many of the above was/were contemporary(s) of Imperial Cholas?
questions.explanation: The Pandyas, Cheras, Chalukyas, and Lambakannas were all contemporary to the Imperial Cholas at different points in time.

questions.question: Which among the following correctly represents the Chola administrative units in ascending order?
questions.explanation: The Chola empire's administrative divisions were Mandalam (province), Valanadu (sub-province), and Nadu (district).

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Rajendra Chola I naval expedition: 1. Rajendra Chola I led successful naval expeditions to Southeast Asia, including the Srivijaya Empire. 2. These expeditions were primarily aimed at establishing trade dominance and expanding maritime influence.

options.text: Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is the correct explanation for Statement-I.
Both Statement-I and Statement-II are correct and Statement-II is not the correct explanation for Statement-I.
Statement-I is correct but Statement-II is incorrect.
Statement-I is incorrect but Statement-II is correct.

questions.explanation: Rajendra Chola I's naval expeditions, particularly against the Srivijaya Empire, aimed to control trade routes and project power in Southeast Asia.

questions.question: With reference to medieval Indian history, the term ‘Munhiyans’ refers to:

options.text: Coins issued by the Delhi Sultanate

questions.explanation: Munhiyans were local spies or informers employed to gather intelligence, particularly about officials and influential figures.

questions.question: With reference to Delhi Sultanate, which of the following statement is not correct:

options.text: Alauddin Khilji gave Amir Khusru the title “Tuti-i-Hind"
Alauddin was the first Sultan to establish a large permanent standing army, which he paid for with cash from the royal treasury.
Jalaluddin Khilji gives Alauddin Khilji the title of Sikander-i-Azam for his victory over Deccan.
To control the prices, Alauddin set up three different markets for different commodities in Delhi.

questions.explanation: Alauddin Khilji himself adopted the title of Sikander-i-Azam, not Jalaluddin Khilji.

questions.question: With reference to the Delhi Sultanate, consider the following statements: 1. Shiqs - Wali 2. Pargana - Muqtis 3. Iqtas - Amil
questions.explanation: The pairs are incorrect, as Shiqs were under Shiqdar, Pargana under Amil, and Iqtas were under Muqtis.

questions.question: With reference to the medieval Indian history ‘Grahi’ and ‘Chari’ were related to:

options.text: Detailed description about soldiers and branding of horses

questions.explanation: Grahi was house tax and Chari was pasture tax imposed by Alauddin Khilji.

questions.question: With reference to the medieval Indian history, consider the following statements: 1. Mahmud Ghazni defeated Anandpal in the first Battle of Waihind. 2. Mahmud Ghazni patronised Al Biruni and Firdausi. 3. Mahmud Gazni appointed Muhammad Ghori as the governor of India while leaving India.
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect, Mahmud Ghazni defeated Jayapala, not Anandpal, in the first Battle of Waihind.

questions.question: Consider the following statements: 1. Qutub-ud-din Aibak shifted his capital from Lahore to Delhi 2. Mongols under Genghis Khan attacked India during Iltutmish period.
questions.explanation: Statement 1 is incorrect as Iltutmish shifted the capital, not Aibak. Statement 2 is incorrect as the Mongols under Genghis Khan did not attack during Iltutmish's period.

questions.question: Consider the following: 1. Paibos 2. Sijada 3. Lakh Baksh 4. Turkan-i-chahalgani Which of the above terms are related to Balban?
questions.explanation: Balban introduced Paibos and Sijada. Lakh Baksh is related to Aibak, and Turkan-i-chahalgani is related to Iltutmish.

questions.question: With reference to medieval Indian history, consider the following statements: 1. Giyasuddin Tughlaq - Khazain-ul-Futuh 2. Al Biruni - Kitab-al Hind 3. Amir Khusro - Tabaqat-i-Nasari How many of the pair(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation: Pair 1 and 3 are incorrect. Amir Khusrau wrote "Khazain-ul-Futuh," and Minhaj-us-Siraj wrote "Tabaqat-i-Nasari." Pair 2 is correct.

questions.question: The Medieval India Book ‘Tughlaq Nama’, was written by:
questions.explanation:
Option (b) is correct
• The "Tughlaq Nama," also known as the "Tughlaq Nama-i-Ala'i," is a historical Persian text written by
Amir Khusrau, a prominent 14th-century poet, historian, and scholar in the Delhi Sultanate.
• Amir Khusrau’s Tughlaq Nama celebrates victories of Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq.
• From Tughlaq Nama we could get details of the early career of the founder of the Tughlaq dynasty.
Option (a) is incorrect
• Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq (c.1320–25 CE) was the founder of the Tughlaq dynasty and the first Sultan to
take the title of Ghazi/ Slayer of Infidels.
• Built a strong fort called Tughlaqabad near Delhi.
• Dispatched his son, Jauna Khan /Mohammad Bin Tughlaq, to re-establish authority in Warangal (Kakatiyas) and Madurai (Pandayas).
• Had a troublesome relationship with the Sufi saint, Sheikh Nizamuddin Aulia.
Option (c) is incorrect
• Abu Rayhan al-Biruni, born in 973 CE in Khwarezm (present-day Uzbekistan), was a polymath scholar
whose contributions spanned astronomy, mathematics, geography, and the natural sciences during the
Islamic Golden Age.
• Al-Biruni made significant advancements in the fields of astronomy and mathematics, developing accurate astronomical tables and refining the calculation of the Earth's circumference.
• He also conducted extensive studies in geography, producing detailed maps and writings on various
regions, including India.
• Al-Biruni's comprehensive work, "Kitab al-Qanun al-Masudi" (The Canon Masudicus), compiled and
systematized knowledge from Greek, Indian, Persian, and Arabic sources, becoming a seminal text in
medieval science.
Option (d) is incorrect
• Muhammad bin Tughlaq, who ruled the Delhi Sultanate from 1325 to 1351, is a figure often remembered for his ambitious yet controversial reign.
• Ascending to power after his father Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq's death, Muhammad bin Tughlaq inherited
an empire extending from present-day Afghanistan to southern India.
• He implemented several innovative policies, such as introducing token currency and shifting the
capital from Delhi to Daulatabad, aiming to centralize administration and defend against Mongol invasions.
• However, these reforms often backfired, leading to economic instability and public discontent.
• Muhammad bin Tughlaq's military campaigns and administrative experiments strained the empire's resources and led to widespread revolts.
• Despite his intellectual pursuits in literature, science, and theology, his reign is marked by its turbulent
nature and the challenges he faced in balancing governance with his ambitious vision for the Delhi Sultanate

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the reign of Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq:
1. He Strengthened defence of North-West frontier to check Mongol invasion.
2. He defeated Qutubdin Mubarak shah in the Battle of Lahrawat.
3. He improved postal system for communication.
Which of the statements given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq, the founder of the Tughlaq dynasty in 1320, prioritized the defence of the
north-western frontier of the Delhi Sultanate to deter Mongol invasions.
• Recognizing the strategic vulnerability posed by frequent Mongol incursions, he fortified key border
regions and established garrisons to bolster military readiness.
• His proactive measures included enhancing the infrastructure of fortresses and deploying troops along
strategic points to repel potential threats.
• By strengthening the defence of the north-western frontier, Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq aimed to safeguard his
realm from external aggressions, thereby securing stability and sovereignty for the Delhi Sultanate during
his reign.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq decisively defeated Khusrau Shah, last ruler of the Khilji dynasty in the Battle
of Lahrawat in 1320, solidifying his authority as the Sultan of Delhi.
• The battle marked a significant turning point in Delhi Sultanate's history, leading to the end of the Khilji
dynasty's rule and the establishment of the Tughlaq dynasty.
• Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq's victory not only secured his position as the new ruler but also demonstrated his
military prowess and determination to consolidate power in the region.
• This event laid the foundation for the Tughlaq dynasty's subsequent expansion and governance over
northern India during the medieval period.
Statement 3 is correct
• Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq implemented a sophisticated postal system during his reign as Sultan of Delhi,
aimed at enhancing communication and administrative efficiency across his vast empire.
• Recognizing the need for reliable communication networks to govern effectively, he improved the network of postal stations equipped with horses and messengers stationed at regular intervals.

questions.question: Medieval Indian city, Tughlaqabad was built by:
questions.explanation:
Ghiyasuddin Tughlaq, during his short reign (ad1320–24), built Tughlaqabad, the fortified city, spanning
across nearly 6.5 km.
• Designed as a strategic stronghold and a symbol of his authority, Tughlaqabad featured massive fortifications with high walls and bastions, making it an imposing structure

questions.question:
Consider the following:
1. Jaunpur
2. Fatehabad
3. Hisar
4. Jahanpanah
5. Dinpanah
How many of the following cities were built during reign of Firoz shah Tughlaq?
questions.explanation:
Option 1 is correct
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq, Sultan of Delhi from 1351 to 1388, commissioned the city of Jaunpur on the banks
of the Gomti River in present-day Uttar Pradesh.
• Founded around 1360, Jaunpur was strategically located to enhance trade and political influence in the
region.
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq envisioned Jaunpur as a tribute to his cousin and predecessor, Mohammad bin Tughlaq, aiming to establish it as a flourishing urban centre.
• The city thrived under subsequent rulers of the Sharqi dynasty, becoming renowned for its architectural
achievements, including grand mosques, tombs, and palaces.
• Jaunpur also served as a hub of Islamic learning and cultural exchange, fostering a rich cultural and
intellectual environment during the medieval period in India.
Option 2 and 3 are correct
• Firoz Shah initiated the construction of cities like Hisar and Fatehabad in present-day Haryana, India.
• These cities were strategically located to enhance defence and administrative control over the northwest
frontier of the Delhi Sultanate.
• Hisar, situated on important trade routes, became a key military and administrative centre with fortified
structures and urban amenities.
• Fatehabad, founded nearby, served as another significant urban settlement under his reign.
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq's construction of these cities aimed to bolster territorial stability and facilitate
governance, reflecting his efforts to fortify the northern frontiers and expand the Sultanate's influence
in the region during the 14th century.
Option 4 is incorrect
• The city of Jahanpanah was established by Muhammad bin Tughlaq, who ruled the Delhi Sultanate
from 1325 to 1351.
• It was envisioned as a fortified city and a refuge for the populace of Delhi during turbulent times.
• Muhammad bin Tughlaq initiated the construction of Jahanpanah after shifting his capital from Delhi
to Daulatabad (Deogiri) in present-day Maharashtra and subsequently returning to Delhi.
• Although originally intended as a haven, the city faced challenges due to its vast size and inadequate
resources, leading to its eventual decline.
• Jahanpanah remains significant in Delhi's history as a testament to the ambitious urban planning efforts
of the Tughlaq dynasty during the medieval period in India.
Option 5 is incorrect
• The city of Dinpanah, meaning "Refuge of the Faithful," was founded by the Mughal Emperor Humayun
in 1533-34.
• Located near Delhi's Purana Qila (Old Fort), Dinpanah was intended to serve as a new capital city and a
refuge for Humayun and his followers after their return from exile.
• The construction of Dinpanah included impressive structures such as forts, palaces, and mosques, designed to accommodate the Mughal court and administration.
• However, Humayun's reign was marked by instability, and he could not fully establish Dinpanah as his
capital before his untimely death in 1556.
• Subsequently, his son Akbar abandoned Dinpanah in favour of Agra and Fatehpur Sikri as Mughal
capitals.

questions.question:
How many of the following reforms were made during the reign of Mohammed
bin Tughlaq?
1. Capital transfer from Delhi to Devagiri (Daulatabad) for better administration.
2. Introduction of Token Currency.
3. The use of liquor and intoxicants was prohibited.
4. Chehra and Dagh System was introduced.
Select the correct answer using the code given below:
questions.explanation:
Statements 1 and 2 are correct
• Muhammad bin Tughlaq, who ruled the Delhi Sultanate from 1325 to 1351, is remembered for his
ambitious administrative reforms, although many of them were met with mixed results and controversy.
• One of his notable initiatives was the introduction of token currency, an attempt to streamline the
economy by replacing copper coins with leather tokens.
• However, this move was poorly received and led to economic chaos, with widespread counterfeiting
and a loss of confidence in the currency system.
• Another significant reform was Muhammad bin Tughlaq's decision to shift the capital from Delhi to
Daulatabad in the Deccan, aimed at centralizing administration and defending against Mongol invasions
from the north-west.
• The arduous relocation process imposed heavy burdens on the populace, resulting in substantial human
and economic costs.
• Despite these challenges, Muhammad bin Tughlaq also implemented measures to improve governance
and welfare.
• He expanded the network of canals for irrigation, promoted agricultural development, and invested
in infrastructure projects to stimulate the economy.
• Muhammad bin Tughlaq's reign, marked by ambitious yet controversial reforms, underscores his vision
for a centralized and efficient state but also highlights the complexities and difficulties of implementing
sweeping changes in a diverse and sprawling empire like the Delhi Sultanate.
Statements 3 and 4 are incorrect
• Alauddin Khilji, who ruled the Delhi Sultanate from 1296 to 1316, is renowned for his extensive administrative reforms that aimed to strengthen central authority and enhance governance efficiency.
• The use of liquor and intoxicants was prohibited by Alauddin Khilji.
• One of his most significant reforms was the introduction of the market reform system.
 Alauddin wanted to maintain a large army; he, therefore, lowered and fixed the price of the commodities of daily use.
 To control the prices, Alauddin set up three different markets for different commodities in Delhi:
grain market (Mandi), cloth market (Sarai Adl) and the market for horses, slaves, cattle, etc.
 To ensure implementation, Alauddin appointed a superintendent (Shahna-i-Mandi) who was assisted by an intelligence officer.
 Alauddin received daily reports of the market from Barid (intelligence officer) and munhiyans (secret spies).
 Diwan-i-Riyasat, a separate department, was established under the command of Naib-i-Riyasat.
Every merchant was registered with the Market Department.
• Military Reforms of Alauddin Khilji:
 Alauddin was the first Sultan to establish a large permanent standing army, which he paid for
with cash from the royal treasury.
 He established an innovative Chehra and Dagh System, in which the Chehra (full description of each
soldier) and Dagh (Horse branding) were preserved.

questions.question:
Consider the following pairs regarding medieval Indian terms:
Terms Meaning
1. Diwan i Bandagan Department of slaves
2. Dar-ul-Shafa Department of charity
3. Diwan-i-Khairat Free hospitals
4. Karkhanas Royal factories
How many of the pair(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is correct
• During the reign of Firoz Shah Tughlaq (1351-1388), the "Diwan-i-Bandagan" was an institution established to oversee and manage the royal slaves and household servants within the Delhi Sultanate.
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq, known for his administrative reforms and benevolent policies, organized the slaves
and servants into different categories based on their skills and duties.
• The Diwan-i-Bandagan played a crucial role in supervising their welfare, the distribution of duties, and
ensuring their loyalty to the Sultanate.
Pair 2 is incorrect
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq, known for his patronage of public works and welfare initiatives, founded Dar-ulShafa to offer healthcare services to the underprivileged and marginalized sections of society.
• It served as a hospital where medical treatment and care were provided free of charge to the sick and
needy.
Pair 3 is incorrect
• Diwan-i-Khairat was an important charitable institution established to provide relief to the poor and
needy in the Delhi Sultanate.
• It operated as a department responsible for distributing stipends, food grains, and other provisions to
widows, orphans, disabled individuals, and impoverished residents across the empire.
Pair 4 is correct
• Karkhanas or royal factories were established as industrial centre's aimed at promoting manufacturing
and craftsmanship within the Delhi Sultanate.
• These factories were equipped with skilled artisans and craftsmen who were employed in producing various goods and commodities for royal use and trade.
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq encouraged the development of these karkhanas to stimulate the economy, create
employment opportunities, and enhance the quality of goods produced under royal patronage.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding Firoz Shah Tughlaq:
1. He wrote the Futuhat-e-firozshahi.
2. The British called him as the father of the irrigation department because of the gardens and canals
that he built.
3. Planned the new city of Jaunpur at the bank of the Gomati River in memory of Mohammad bin Tughlaq.
How many of the statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq, the Sultan of Delhi from 1351 to 1388, authored the " Futuhat-e-firozshahi" a
significant historical and administrative document.
• This work, composed in Persian, chronicles his achievements, policies, and the state of the Delhi Sultanate
during his reign.
• It serves as both a memoir and a detailed account of his governance, including his public works projects,
religious endowments, and administrative reforms aimed at improving the welfare of his subjects.
Statement 2 is correct
• The British bestowed upon Firoz Shah Tughlaq the title "Father of the Irrigation Department" due to
his significant contributions in developing gardens and canals during his reign as Sultan of Delhi.
• He was the first Sultan to impose Sharb (irrigation tax).
• But at the same time, he built number of canals and also set up a separate department of public
works.
 Sirsa to Hansi
 Sutlej to Hansi: Longest canal (about 200 kilometres)
 Yamuna to Hissar
Statement 3 is correct
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq planned and founded the city of Jaunpur on the banks of the Gomati River in
present-day Uttar Pradesh, as a memorial to his cousin and predecessor, Mohammad bin Tughlaq.
• Established around 1360, Jaunpur became a significant urban centre known for its strategic location and
architectural splendour during the Delhi Sultanate period.
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq's decision to establish Jaunpur was both a political and commemorative gesture,
aiming to honour Mohammad bin Tughlaq's legacy while expanding the Sultanate's influence in the region.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements regarding the Delhi Sultanate:
1. Chenghis khan appointed Khizr Khan as Governor of Multan, and Khizr Khan captured Delhi and
founded the Sayyid dynasty in 1414.
2. Lodhis were the last ruling family of Sultanate period and first to be headed by Afghans.
3. Bahlul Lodhi Introduced Gaz-i-Sikandari for measuring agricultural land.
Which of the following statement(s) given above is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Timur, the Central Asian conqueror, appointed Khizr Khan as the governor of Multan in the early 15th
century.
• Khizr Khan, seizing an opportunity amidst the declining authority of the Tughlaq dynasty in Delhi, led an
expedition that culminated in the capture of Delhi in 1414.
• This marked the establishment of the Sayyid dynasty, named after Khizr Khan's lineage as a descendant
of Prophet Muhammad (hence Sayyid).
• The Sayyid dynasty ruled over Delhi Sultanate for nearly four decades, navigating challenges such as
regional conflicts and the aftermath of Timur's invasion, while contributing to the cultural and administrative continuity of the Delhi Sultanate during this period.
Statement 2 is correct
• The Lodhi dynasty marked the culmination of the Sultanate period in India, led by Afghan rulers.
• Bahlul Khan Lodhi, a prominent Afghan noble, established the Lodhi dynasty after overthrowing the
weakened Sayyid dynasty in 1451.
• The Lodhis were the first ruling family of the Delhi Sultanate to be predominantly Afghan, marking a
shift from the earlier Turkic and Persian ruling elites.
• Under rulers like Sikandar Lodhi and Ibrahim Lodhi, the dynasty stabilized and expanded its territories,
but faced internal challenges and external threats, eventually succumbing to the Mughal Empire under
Babur in 1526 at the Battle of Panipat.
• The Lodhi period is noted for its administrative reforms, military prowess, and the establishment of a
distinct Afghan influence in the history of medieval India.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• Sikandar Lodhi, the Sultan of Delhi from 1489 to 1517, introduced the Gaz-i-Sikandari, a standardized
unit of measurement used specifically for agricultural land.
• This measurement was defined as approximately 32 inches in length.
• The Gaz-i-Sikandari facilitated uniformity and accuracy in determining land area, which was crucial for
taxation, administration, and land tenure systems during his reign.

questions.question:
Consider the following statements:
1. Muhmmed bin Tughlaq started the department of slaves.
2. Alauddin Khilji conducted the Quarachil Expedition.
3. Firoz Shah Tughlaq made the Iqta system hereditary.
How many of the above statement(s) is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is incorrect
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq, who ruled the Delhi Sultanate from 1351 to 1388, is credited with numerous administrative reforms and public works.
• One of his notable initiatives was the establishment of the "Diwan-i-Bandagan," or the Department of
Slaves.
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq's establishment of this department was part of his broader effort to improve the
administration and welfare of the state.
Statement 2 is incorrect
• Muhammad bin Tughlaq, during his reign as the Sultan of Delhi from 1325 to 1351, was known for his
ambitious military campaigns and administrative reforms.
• He conducted a military campaign known as the Quarachil Expedition. This expedition was apparently
aimed at the Kulu-Kangra region of Himachal
• This expedition was part of his efforts to assert control over the Himalayan territories and secure strategic
positions in the northern parts of his empire.
• The failure of such expeditions reflected the complexities of governing a diverse and expansive empire,
where geographic and cultural differences posed significant challenges to central authority.
Statement 3 is correct
• Firoz Shah Tughlaq, during his reign from 1351 to 1388, introduced reforms to the Iqta system, allowing
certain Iqtas to become hereditary.

questions.question:
With reference to the Delhi Sultanate, Consider the following statements:
1. The Ghulam Dynasty had the greatest number of sultans in Delhi Sultanate.
2. Tughlaq Dynasty ruled maximum period in Delhi Sultanate.
3. Khilji Dynasty ruled in least territory.
How many of the above statement(s) is/are correct?
questions.explanation:
Statement 1 is correct
• The Ghulam Dynasty, also known as the Slave Dynasty, had the greatest number of sultans in the
history of the Delhi Sultanate.
• Established by Qutb-ud-din Aibak in 1206, the dynasty is notable for its succession of rulers who were
originally slaves, reflecting the unique socio-political structure of the period.
• The Slave Dynasty saw a total of ten sultans ruling Delhi, more than any other dynasty in the Sultanate's
history.
• These sultans, including prominent figures like Iltutmish, Raziya Sultana and Balban, played crucial roles
in consolidating and expanding the Sultanate's territories, as well as in establishing administrative and
military frameworks that influenced subsequent rulers.
Statement 2 is correct
• The Tughlaq Dynasty ruled the Delhi Sultanate for the longest period compared to other dynasties.
• Established by Ghiyas-ud-din Tughlaq in 1320, the dynasty marked a significant era in the history of the
Sultanate, lasting until 1414.
• During its nearly century-long reign, the Tughlaq Dynasty saw a series of ambitious and, at times, controversial rulers, who were known for their attempts to expand and consolidate their empire, as well as
for various administrative and economic reforms.
• One of the most notable rulers was Muhammad bin Tughlaq, whose reign (1325-1351) was marked
by ambitious projects such as the transfer of the capital from Delhi to Daulatabad and the introduction
of token currency.
• However, many of his policies, although innovative, led to economic turmoil and discontent among the
populace. Another significant ruler was Firuz Shah Tughlaq, who ruled from 1351 to 1388.
• He is remembered for his administrative reforms, public works, and efforts to improve the agrarian
economy. Firuz Shah's reign saw the construction of numerous canals, rest houses, and hospitals, as
well as the establishment of new towns.
• The last ruler of the Tughlaq Dynasty, Nasir-ud-Din Mahmud Tughlaq, faced significant challenges in
maintaining control, leading to the eventual decline and replacement of the dynasty by the Sayyid Dynasty in 1414.
Statement 3 is incorrect
• The Sayyid Dynasty ruled over the smallest territory compared to other dynasties of the Delhi Sultanate.
• Established in 1414 by Khizr Khan, a former governor under the Tughlaq Dynasty, the Sayyid rulers controlled a significantly diminished realm due to the declining power of the Sultanate and increasing regional fragmentation.
• The Sayyids faced continuous challenges from regional powers and internal rebellions, which restricted
their authority largely to the region around Delhi.
• The dynasty lasted until 1451, when it was replaced by the Lodhi Dynasty.
• The Sayyid Dynasty's limited territorial control reflected the broader decline of centralized authority in
the late Delhi Sultanate period.

questions.question: With reference to medieval India, the term ‘Banjaras’ refers to:
questions.explanation:
Option (a) is correct
• The Banjaras were traders who played a crucial role in transporting grains and other goods from villages
to Delhi during the period of the Delhi Sultanate.
• They were a nomadic community known for their expertise in long-distance trade and transportation.
• Utilizing large caravans of bullock carts, the Banjaras ensured a steady supply of essential commodities
like grains to urban canters, facilitating economic stability and the sustenance of large populations in
cities like Delhi.
Option (b) is incorrect
• The term "Bandagan" refers to slaves or servants in the Delhi Sultanate.
• These individuals often played significant roles in the administration and military.
• Many slaves, or "bandagan," were brought from Central Asia and other regions, and over time, they could
rise to prominent positions due to their loyalty and abilities.
• In the Delhi Sultanate, some of these slaves became powerful military commanders, governors, and even
sultans, as seen in the case of the Slave Dynasty (Ghulam Dynasty).
Option (c) is incorrect
• The term "Munhiyan" refers to secret agents or informants in the Delhi Sultanate. These individuals were
employed by the rulers to gather intelligence, monitor the activities of nobles and other officials, and
report on various matters of state security and administration.
• The Munhiyan played a crucial role in maintaining internal stability and ensuring the ruler was well-informed about potential threats, conspiracies, and the general state of the realm.
Option (d) is incorrect
• Qazis were the judicial officials responsible for interpreting and implementing Sharia (Islamic law) in
the courts of Delhi Sultanate.
• They played a crucial role in the administration of justice, overseeing civil and criminal cases according
to Islamic legal principles

questions.question:
With reference to the administration of the Delhi Sultanate, consider the following pairs:
Heads Portfolios
1. Diwan-i-Kohi Military department
2. Diwan-i-Insha Department of Correspondence
3. Diwan-i- Bandagan Department of slaves
4. Diwan-i-Ariz Department of Agriculture
How many of the above pair(s) is/are correctly matched?
questions.explanation:
Pair 1 is incorrect
• The "Diwan-i-Kohi" referred to the Department of Agriculture in the administrative setup of Delhi
Sultanate in India.
• It was responsible for overseeing and managing agricultural affairs within the realm.
• The term "Diwan" denotes an office or department, while "Kohi" specifically relates to agriculture or
land cultivation.
• Under the Diwan-i-Kohi, various tasks related to agriculture were handled, including land surveys, assessment of agricultural productivity, collection of land revenue (often based on agricultural output), and the
implementation of irrigation projects to enhance agricultural productivity.
Pair 2 is correct
• The "Diwan-i-Insha" was the Department of Correspondence in the administrative structure of Delhi
Sultanate in India.
• "Insha" refers to correspondence or writing. The Diwan-i-Insha was responsible for managing official correspondence within the administration. This included drafting and sending letters, reports, and official
communications on behalf of the ruler or government officials.
• In addition to handling routine correspondence, the Diwan-i-Insha played a crucial role in diplomatic
relations with neighbouring states, trading partners, and allies.
• Diplomatic letters, treaties, and agreements were drafted and managed by this department, contributing
to the maintenance of political alliances and international relations.
Pair 3 is correct
• The "Diwan-i-Bandagan" was the department responsible for managing slaves in the administrative
system of medieval Islamic states, including during the Delhi Sultanate in India.
• The term "Bandagan" specifically denotes slaves or servants.
• In the context of the Delhi Sultanate, the Diwan-i-Bandagan oversaw various aspects related to slaves
within the state. This included the acquisition, management, and deployment of slaves for various purposes such as domestic service, agricultural labor, military service, and administrative roles.
Pair 4 is incorrect
• The "Diwan-i-Ariz" was the military department in the administrative structure of medieval Islamic
