questions.explanation: Article 355 of the Constitution provides that "It shall be the duty of the Union to protect every State against external aggression and internal disturbance and to ensure that the government of every State is carried on in accordance with the provisions of this Constitution." This Article imposes a duty on the Union government to protect states and ensures constitutional governance, serving as a constitutional basis for central intervention in state affairs.

questions.question: Under which of the following circumstances can a person be deprived of citizenship under the Constitution of India?

options.text: If a person has acquired citizenship by fraud
If a person has shown disloyalty to the Constitution of India
If a person resides outside India for seven years continuously
If a person acquires citizenship of another country

questions.explanation: A person can be deprived of citizenship if they have acquired it by fraud. According to the Citizenship Act, 1955, under Section 10, the central government may deprive a person of citizenship if it was obtained by means of fraud, false representation, or concealment of material facts. However, citizenship cannot be taken away on grounds of disloyalty to the Constitution, residence abroad, or dual citizenship (which is not permitted under Indian law).

questions.question: Which Amendment Act introduced changes to the Preamble of the Constitution of India?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment Act, 1976 introduced changes to the Preamble of the Constitution of India. This amendment added three new words to the Preamble: "SOCIALIST," "SECULAR," and "INTEGRITY." The original Preamble declared India as a "Sovereign Democratic Republic," which was changed to a "Sovereign Socialist Secular Democratic Republic." It also changed "unity of the nation" to "unity and integrity of the nation."

questions.question: The system of judicial review in the Indian Constitution is based on which of the following principles?
questions.explanation: The system of judicial review in the Indian Constitution is based on the principle of constitutional supremacy. This principle establishes the Constitution as the supreme law of the land, and any law that contravenes constitutional provisions can be struck down by the judiciary. Unlike the UK's parliamentary sovereignty model, in India, both Parliament and state legislatures are subordinate to the Constitution, and their acts are subject to judicial scrutiny.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Vice President of India is NOT correct?

options.text: He is the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha
He can vote in the Rajya Sabha in case of a tie
His election can be challenged in the Supreme Court
He must be qualified for election as a member of the Lok Sabha

questions.explanation: The statement "He must be qualified for election as a member of the Lok Sabha" is NOT correct regarding the Vice President of India. Under Article 66, to be eligible for the Vice President's office, a person must be qualified for election as a member of the Rajya Sabha (not Lok Sabha). Other qualifications include being a citizen of India, at least 35 years of age, and not holding any office of profit under government.

questions.question: The 'Doctrine of Lapse' was introduced during the Governor-Generalship of:
questions.explanation: The 'Doctrine of Lapse' was introduced during the Governor-Generalship of Lord Dalhousie, who served from 1848 to 1856. Under this policy, if a ruler died without a natural heir (son), his kingdom would "lapse" and become part of British India. Dalhousie used this doctrine to annex several princely states including Satara (1848), Jhansi (1853), Nagpur (1854), and Awadh (1856, though technically on grounds of misgovernance).

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding the Attorney General of India: 1. He is appointed by the President of India 2. He must have the same qualifications as a Supreme Court Judge 3. He has the right to speak and take part in proceedings of both Houses of Parliament 4. He is a member of the Council of Ministers. Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1 and 3 are correct. The Attorney General is appointed by the President under Article 76 and has the right to speak and participate in parliamentary proceedings (though cannot vote). Statement 2 is incorrect as the Attorney General must be qualified to be appointed as a Supreme Court Judge (not having the same qualifications as existing judges). Statement 4 is incorrect as the Attorney General is not a member of the Council of Ministers.

questions.question: The concept of 'reasonable restrictions' on Fundamental Rights is associated with which of the following Articles?
questions.explanation: The concept of 'reasonable restrictions' on Fundamental Rights is associated with Article 19 of the Constitution. Article 19 guarantees six freedoms to citizens (speech, assembly, association, movement, residence, and profession), but clauses (2) to (6) authorize the State to impose 'reasonable restrictions' on these freedoms in the interests of sovereignty, integrity, public order, decency, morality, and other specified grounds, subject to judicial review.

questions.question: Which of the following writs is issued by a court to an inferior court or tribunal to prevent it from exceeding its jurisdiction?
questions.explanation: The writ of Prohibition is issued by a higher court to an inferior court or tribunal to prevent it from exceeding its jurisdiction or acting contrary to the rules of natural justice. It is a preventive remedy that stops the lower court from proceeding with a case outside its jurisdiction, unlike certiorari which is issued after the decision has been made.

questions.question: Which of the following provisions was NOT part of the original Constitution and was added later by an amendment?
questions.explanation: Fundamental Duties were NOT part of the original Constitution and were added later by the 42nd Amendment Act in 1976 based on the recommendations of the Swaran Singh Committee. The Directive Principles of State Policy (Part IV), Election Commission (Article 324), and provisions related to elections were all included in the original Constitution adopted in 1949. The Panchayati Raj Institutions gained constitutional status through the 73rd Amendment in 1992.

questions.question: In the context of the Indian judiciary, which of the following is NOT a feature of Public Interest Litigation (PIL)?

options.text: Relaxation of the rule of locus standi

questions.explanation: Adversarial in nature is NOT a feature of Public Interest Litigation (PIL). PILs are distinctly non-adversarial in nature, where the court may assume a more active role compared to traditional adversarial litigation. PILs feature relaxed rules of locus standi (allowing any public-spirited person to file cases for others), courts can act suo moto (on their own), and the process is collaborative rather than contesting parties fighting against each other.

questions.question: Which Schedule of the Indian Constitution contains provisions regarding anti-defection law?
questions.explanation: The Tenth Schedule of the Indian Constitution contains provisions regarding the anti-defection law. Added by the 52nd Amendment Act in 1985, it provides for disqualification of elected members on grounds of defection (switching political parties after election). The law aims to prevent political instability caused by party-hopping and applies to members of both Parliament and state legislatures.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT included in the Right to Freedom of Religion under the Indian Constitution?

options.text: Right to profess, practice and propagate religion
Right to establish and maintain religious institutions

questions.explanation: Freedom from religious taxes is NOT explicitly included in the Right to Freedom of Religion under Articles 25-28 of the Indian Constitution. While Article 27 prohibits compulsory payment of taxes for promotion of a particular religion, it does not broadly exempt individuals from all religious taxes. The other options—freedom of conscience, right to profess/practice/propagate religion, and right to establish/maintain religious institutions—are all protected under Articles 25 and 26.

questions.question: Which of the following is the CORRECT chronological order of establishment?

options.text: Planning Commission, NITI Aayog, Finance Commission, Election Commission
Election Commission, Finance Commission, Planning Commission, NITI Aayog
Finance Commission, Election Commission, Planning Commission, NITI Aayog
Election Commission, Planning Commission, Finance Commission, NITI Aayog

questions.explanation: The correct chronological order of establishment is: Election Commission (January 25, 1950), Finance Commission (established under Article 280, operational from 1951), Planning Commission (March 15, 1950, non-constitutional body), NITI Aayog (January 1, 2015, replaced Planning Commission). The Election Commission was established immediately before the Constitution came into effect, while the Finance Commission was provided in the Constitution but became operational slightly later.

questions.question: Under which article of the Constitution can the Supreme Court issue advisory opinion on matters referred by the President of India?
questions.explanation: Under Article 143 of the Constitution, the Supreme Court can issue advisory opinions on matters referred by the President of India. This provision allows the President to seek the Court's opinion on questions of law or fact that have arisen or are likely to arise, which are of public importance. The Court may, after such hearing as it thinks fit, report its opinion to the President, though this opinion is not binding.

questions.question: Which of the following provisions of the Indian Constitution cannot be amended by the Parliament?

options.text: The basic structure of the Constitution
The Directive Principles of State Policy
The composition of the Council of Ministers

questions.explanation: The basic structure of the Constitution cannot be amended by the Parliament. This limitation was established in the landmark Kesavananda Bharati case (1973), where the Supreme Court held that while Parliament can amend any part of the Constitution under Article 368, it cannot alter or destroy its basic structure or framework. The other provisions mentioned—election of President, Directive Principles, and composition of Council of Ministers—can be amended through the prescribed procedure.

questions.question: Which among the following is NOT a constitutional body?
questions.explanation: NITI Aayog is NOT a constitutional body. It was established in 2015 by a resolution of the Union Cabinet to replace the Planning Commission and functions as a policy think tank of the Government of India. The Finance Commission (Article 280), National Commission for SCs (Article 338), and NHRC (though initially established by statute, has constitutional recognition through Article 338A) all have constitutional backing.

questions.question: Which part of the Indian Constitution deals with Centre-State relations?
questions.explanation: Part XI of the Indian Constitution deals with Centre-State relations. This part, titled "Relations between the Union and the States," comprises Articles 245 to 263 and covers legislative relations (Articles 245-255), administrative relations (Articles 256-263), and distribution of powers between the Union and States through the three lists in the Seventh Schedule—Union List, State List, and Concurrent List.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Indian citizenship is correct?

options.text: Dual citizenship is allowed for all Indian citizens
A person can acquire citizenship through registration if married to an Indian citizen for at least 2 years
A foreigner can acquire citizenship through naturalization after residing in India for at least 10 years
A child born outside India after 26th January, 1950 is a citizen by descent if either of the parents is a citizen of India at the time of birth

questions.explanation: A person can acquire citizenship through registration if married to an Indian citizen for at least 2 years. This is correct as per Section 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act, 1955. The other statements are incorrect: India does not permit dual citizenship (though OCI is available); naturalization requires residence for at least 11 years (not 10); and a child born outside India after December 3, 2004 is a citizen by descent only if one parent is an Indian citizen and the birth is registered at an Indian consulate.

questions.question: Who among the following appoints the Chairperson of the National Human Rights Commission?

options.text: A committee comprising the Prime Minister, Home Minister, and Leaders of Opposition in both Houses

questions.explanation: The President appoints the Chairperson of the National Human Rights Commission. However, the appointment is made based on the recommendation of a committee consisting of the Prime Minister (chairperson), the Speaker of Lok Sabha, the Home Minister, the Leaders of Opposition in both Houses of Parliament, and the Deputy Chairperson of Rajya Sabha. The selection process ensures input from both the ruling party and opposition.

questions.question: The concept of 'pocket veto' in the Indian Constitution relates to which of the following?

options.text: President's power to veto a bill
Governor's power to reserve a bill for President's consideration
Speaker's power to disqualify members under the anti-defection law
President's power to keep a bill pending indefinitely

questions.explanation: The concept of 'pocket veto' in the Indian Constitution relates to the President's power to keep a bill pending indefinitely. Unlike a regular veto, where the President expressly rejects a bill, in a pocket veto, the President neither assents to nor returns the bill to the Parliament. The Constitution does not specify any time limit for the President to take action on bills presented for assent, effectively giving the power to indefinitely withhold assent without explicitly rejecting the bill.

questions.question: The Constituent Assembly of India was set up under the provisions of:
questions.explanation: The Constituent Assembly of India was set up under the provisions of the Cabinet Mission Plan of 1946. The Plan proposed a three-tier constitutional structure for India and established the framework for creating the Constituent Assembly to draft India's Constitution. The Assembly first met on December 9, 1946, and Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as its permanent Chairman. The Assembly continued its work after independence until the Constitution was adopted on November 26, 1949.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a feature of the federal system enshrined in the Indian Constitution?

options.text: Division of powers between the Centre and States
Bicameral legislature at both Centre and State levels

questions.explanation: Bicameral legislature at both Centre and State levels is NOT a feature of the federal system enshrined in the Indian Constitution. While the Parliament at the Centre is bicameral (Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha), states have the option to have either unicameral or bicameral legislatures. Most states have unicameral legislatures, with only a few (like Uttar Pradesh, Bihar, Maharashtra, etc.) having opted for bicameralism at different points.

questions.question: The 'Doctrine of Eclipse' as developed by the Supreme Court is related to:

options.text: Conflict between Centre and State laws
Pre-constitutional laws inconsistent with Fundamental Rights

questions.explanation: The 'Doctrine of Eclipse' as developed by the Supreme Court is related to pre-constitutional laws inconsistent with Fundamental Rights. According to this doctrine, a pre-constitutional law that violates fundamental rights is not nullified but becomes unenforceable or remains in a dormant state (eclipsed) to the extent of inconsistency. If the relevant fundamental right is amended to remove the inconsistency, the law becomes active and enforceable again.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the removal of a High Court judge is correct?

options.text: A High Court judge can be removed by the Governor of the state
A High Court judge can be removed in the same manner as a Supreme Court judge
Removal requires a special majority in only the Lok Sabha
A High Court judge can be transferred without impeachment proceedings

questions.explanation: A High Court judge can be removed in the same manner as a Supreme Court judge. Under Article 217(1)(b) read with Article 124(4), a High Court judge can be removed by the President on grounds of proven misbehavior or incapacity. The removal requires an address by each House of Parliament supported by a special majority (majority of total membership and 2/3rds of members present and voting) after an impeachment process.

questions.question: The Ninth Schedule of the Indian Constitution was introduced by which amendment?
questions.explanation: The Ninth Schedule of the Indian Constitution was introduced by the First Amendment Act, 1951. It was created to protect land reform laws from judicial scrutiny under Fundamental Rights, particularly right to property (then under Article 31). Laws placed in this Schedule were originally meant to be immune from judicial review, though the Supreme Court in I.R. Coelho case (2007) held that even Ninth Schedule laws could be reviewed if they violate the basic structure doctrine.

questions.question: In which of the following cases did the Supreme Court of India give the judgement that 'Right to Privacy' is a fundamental right?

options.text: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
Minerva Mills v. Union of India
Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Justice K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India

questions.explanation: The Supreme Court of India gave the judgment that 'Right to Privacy' is a fundamental right in the Justice K.S. Puttaswamy v. Union of India case (2017). In this landmark 9-judge bench unanimous decision, the Court overruled previous judgments and declared privacy as an intrinsic part of the right to life and personal liberty under Article 21 and other freedoms guaranteed in Part III of the Constitution.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Finance Commission is NOT correct?

options.text: It is constituted by the President every five years
It recommends distribution of taxes between Centre and States
It recommends principles governing grants-in-aid to States
Its recommendations are binding on the government

questions.explanation: The statement "Its recommendations are binding on the government" is NOT correct regarding the Finance Commission. While the Finance Commission makes recommendations on the distribution of tax proceeds between the Union and States and principles governing grants-in-aid, these recommendations are not legally binding on the government. The government has the discretion to accept or reject them, though traditionally most recommendations are accepted.

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India: 1. The CAG is appointed by the President. 2. The CAG can be removed in the same manner as a Supreme Court Judge. 3. The CAG is eligible for further government office after retirement. 4. The CAG reports on Union accounts are submitted to the Parliament through the Finance Minister. Which statements are INCORRECT?
questions.explanation: Statements 3 and 4 are INCORRECT. The CAG is NOT eligible for further government office after retirement (Article 148(4) prohibits this to ensure independence). CAG reports are submitted directly to the President/Governor, who causes them to be laid before Parliament/Legislature (not through the Finance Minister). Statements 1 and 2 are correct: The CAG is appointed by the President and can be removed in the same manner as a Supreme Court Judge (impeachment process).

questions.question: Under which article of the Constitution can a proclamation of National Emergency be issued on the grounds of war, external aggression or armed rebellion?
questions.explanation: Under Article 352 of the Constitution, a proclamation of National Emergency can be issued on the grounds of war, external aggression or armed rebellion. Initially, the provision included "internal disturbance" as a ground, but the 44th Amendment Act, 1978 substituted this with "armed rebellion" to prevent misuse. A proclamation under this article must be approved by both Houses of Parliament within one month, or it ceases to operate.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Election Commission of India is NOT correct?

options.text: It conducts elections to the Parliament, State Legislatures, and offices of President and Vice-President
The Constitution provides for a multi-member Election Commission
The Chief Election Commissioner can be removed only through impeachment
The tenure of the Election Commissioner is fixed at six years or age of 65, whichever is earlier

questions.explanation: The statement "The Constitution provides for a multi-member Election Commission" is NOT correct. Originally, Article 324 provided for a single-member Election Commission, with just the Chief Election Commissioner. The multi-member structure (with additional Election Commissioners) came through the Election Commission Act, 1991, not through the original Constitution. The Commission became a three-member body permanently from October 1993.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a feature of the parliamentary form of government in India?

options.text: Collective responsibility of the executive to the legislature
Complete separation of powers between executive and legislature

questions.explanation: Complete separation of powers between executive and legislature is NOT a feature of the parliamentary form of government in India. In fact, the parliamentary system features fusion of executive and legislative powers, as ministers are typically members of Parliament. The other options—collective responsibility, nominal head of state (President), and political homogeneity in the executive (Council of Ministers)—are all features of India's parliamentary system.

questions.question: The provision for Co-operative Societies was included in the Indian Constitution through which Amendment?
questions.explanation: The provision for Co-operative Societies was included in the Indian Constitution through the 97th Amendment Act, 2011. This amendment added a new Part IXB titled "The Co-operative Societies" (Articles 243ZH to 243ZT) and made the right to form co-operative societies a fundamental right by adding Article 19(1)(c). However, in 2021, the Supreme Court struck down parts of the amendment relating to state co-operatives as unconstitutional for not ratifying through state legislatures.

questions.question: The concept of 'Residuary Powers' under the Indian Constitution refers to:

options.text: Powers not mentioned in the Union, State or Concurrent Lists
Powers exclusively reserved for the Union Government
Powers that remain with the Constituent Assembly
Powers that can be exercised during emergency only

questions.explanation: The concept of 'Residuary Powers' under the Indian Constitution refers to powers not mentioned in the Union, State or Concurrent Lists of the Seventh Schedule. Article 248 vests these powers with the Union Government, allowing Parliament to make laws on any matter not enumerated in any of the three lists. This provision ensures that no subject remains unlegislated due to constitutional silence and reflects a centralized federal structure.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the representation of states in the Rajya Sabha is correct?

options.text: States are represented in proportion to their population
Members are directly elected by the people of the state

questions.explanation: States are represented in the Rajya Sabha in proportion to their population. Under Article 80, the allocation of seats varies from 1 to 31 (Uttar Pradesh has the maximum). This statement is correct. The other statements are incorrect: states do not have equal representation (unlike the US Senate); Union Territories do have representation (Delhi and Puducherry); and members are indirectly elected by the elected members of state legislative assemblies through proportional representation by means of a single transferable vote.

questions.question: Which amendment to the Constitution reduced the voting age from 21 years to 18 years?
questions.explanation: The 61st Amendment Act, 1988 reduced the voting age from 21 years to 18 years. This amendment modified Article 326 of the Constitution, which deals with elections to the House of the People and to the Legislative Assemblies of States. The amendment aimed to provide greater participation to youth in the political process and align with global trends of reducing voting age.

questions.question: The concept of 'Police State' is against which of the following principles?
questions.explanation: The concept of 'Police State' is against the principle of Rule of Law. In a police state, government exercises power arbitrarily through police force without proper legal restraints, whereas the Rule of Law principle (advocated by A.V. Dicey) ensures that no person is above the law, government operates within legal framework, and fundamental rights are protected by independent judiciary. The Indian Constitution incorporates the Rule of Law through Articles 14, 19, 21, and others.

questions.question: Which of the following writs is issued by a court to inquire into the legality of a claim of a person to a public office?
questions.explanation: The writ of Quo Warranto is issued by a court to inquire into the legality of a claim of a person to a public office. This writ helps prevent usurpation of public offices by unauthorized persons. It can be issued when: the office is public, created by statute or constitution; the office is substantive in character; the person has assumed office; and the appointment is allegedly in contravention of law.

questions.question: The 'Panchsheel Agreement' signed by India was originally with which country?
questions.explanation: The 'Panchsheel Agreement' was originally signed between India and China on April 29, 1954. Formally titled "Agreement on Trade and Intercourse between Tibet Region of China and India," it incorporated five principles of peaceful coexistence: mutual respect for sovereignty, non-aggression, non-interference in internal affairs, equality and mutual benefit, and peaceful co-existence. These principles later became the foundation of the Non-Aligned Movement.

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding the President's power to grant pardons under Article 72: 1. The President can grant pardon, reprieve, respite, remission, or commutation for punishment for offenses against a Union law 2. The President cannot pardon a death sentence imposed by a Court Martial 3. The President's decision regarding mercy petition is subject to judicial review on procedural grounds 4. The President can grant pardon for a sentence of death confirmed by the High Court but not yet executed Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1 and 3 are correct. Under Article 72, the President can grant pardons for offenses against Union laws, and the Supreme Court in Epuru Sudhakar case (2006) held that the President's decision on mercy petitions is subject to judicial review on procedural grounds. Statement 2 is incorrect as the President can pardon sentences by Court Martial. Statement 4 is incorrect because the President can grant pardons for death sentences confirmed by any court, not just High Courts.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT considered as an All-India Service?
questions.explanation: The Indian Revenue Service (IRS) is NOT considered an All-India Service. Under Article 312, only the Indian Administrative Service (IAS), Indian Police Service (IPS), and Indian Forest Service (IFoS) are categorized as All-India Services, jointly controlled by the Union and States. The IRS is a Central Service (Group A) that operates exclusively under the Union Government, primarily in income tax and customs/excise departments.

questions.question: Which article of the Indian Constitution deals with the procedure for amendment?
questions.explanation: Article 368 of the Indian Constitution deals with the procedure for amendment. Titled "Power of Parliament to amend the Constitution and procedure therefor," it outlines the process by which the Constitution can be amended through a bill passed in each House of Parliament by a special majority (majority of total membership and 2/3rds of members present and voting), and in some cases, requiring ratification by at least half the state legislatures.

questions.question: The 'Bicameral Legislature' concept in India exists at:

options.text: Both at the Centre and all State levels
At the Centre and some State levels

questions.explanation: The 'Bicameral Legislature' concept in India exists at the Centre and some State levels. At the Centre, Parliament consists of two houses: Lok Sabha (lower house) and Rajya Sabha (upper house). At the state level, while all states have a Legislative Assembly (Vidhan Sabha), only some states have a Legislative Council (Vidhan Parishad) as the second chamber. Currently, six states have bicameral legislatures: Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Telangana, and Uttar Pradesh.

questions.question: The phrase 'procedure established by law' in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution was borrowed from which country's constitution?
questions.explanation: The phrase 'procedure established by law' in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution was borrowed from the Constitution of Japan. This concept differs from the American "due process of law" in that it requires only that a law properly enacted by the legislature be followed, rather than subjecting the law itself to standards of fairness and justice. The Supreme Court, however, has over time interpreted Article 21 to incorporate aspects of substantive due process.

questions.question: Which one of the following constitutional amendments introduced the concept of anti-defection in the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: The 52nd Amendment Act, 1985 introduced the concept of anti-defection in the Indian Constitution. This amendment added the Tenth Schedule which contains provisions regarding disqualification of elected representatives on grounds of defection (switching political parties after election). The law was enacted to combat the "Aaya Ram Gaya Ram" syndrome of political defections that had destabilized governments in the 1960s and 1970s.

questions.question: The Constitution (Seventy-Third Amendment) Act, 1992 is related to:
questions.explanation: The Constitution (Seventy-Third Amendment) Act, 1992 is related to Panchayati Raj Institutions. This amendment added Part IX to the Constitution (Articles 243 to 243O) and gave constitutional status to the three-tier Panchayati Raj system (village, intermediate, and district levels). It mandated regular elections, reservation for SC/ST/women, established State Finance Commissions, and empowered panchayats with functions listed in the Eleventh Schedule.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Rajya Sabha is NOT correct?

options.text: It is a permanent House which cannot be dissolved
One-third of its members retire every two years
It has equal powers with the Lok Sabha in amending the Constitution

questions.explanation: The statement "It can initiate Money Bills" is NOT correct about the Rajya Sabha. Under Article 109, Money Bills can be introduced only in the Lok Sabha, not in the Rajya Sabha. The Rajya Sabha can only make recommendations on Money Bills, which the Lok Sabha may accept or reject. The other statements are correct: Rajya Sabha is a permanent house, one-third of its members retire every two years, and it has equal powers with Lok Sabha in amending the Constitution.

questions.question: Under which article of the Constitution does the President of India have the power to consult the Supreme Court on a question of law or fact?
questions.explanation: Under Article 143 of the Constitution, the President of India has the power to consult the Supreme Court on a question of law or fact. This provision, known as the advisory jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, allows the President to refer matters of public importance or matters where a substantial question of law needs interpretation. The Court's opinion in such references is advisory and not binding on the President.

questions.question: Which among the following is NOT included in the concurrent list under the Seventh Schedule of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: Police is NOT included in the concurrent list under the Seventh Schedule of the Indian Constitution. Police is a state subject included in the State List (List II, Entry 1) and is thus under the exclusive jurisdiction of state governments. Education, forests, and marriage and divorce are all included in the Concurrent List (List III) where both the Union and state governments can legislate, with central legislation prevailing in case of conflict.

questions.question: In which of the following cases did the Supreme Court of India declare 'Right to Clean Environment' as a fundamental right?

options.text: Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India
Mohini Jain v. State of Karnataka
M.C. Mehta v. Union of India
Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala

questions.explanation: The Supreme Court of India declared 'Right to Clean Environment' as a fundamental right in the M.C. Mehta v. Union of India case (Oleum Gas Leak case, 1987). The Court interpreted Article 21 (Right to Life) to include the right to a clean, healthy environment. This case and subsequent environmental litigation established that environmental degradation violates the fundamental right to life and personal liberty.

questions.question: Which of the following Schedules of the Indian Constitution contains provisions regarding the administration of Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes?
questions.explanation: The Fifth Schedule of the Indian Constitution contains provisions regarding the administration of Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes in states other than Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, and Mizoram. It provides for the establishment of Tribal Advisory Councils, gives powers to the Governor for the peace and good governance of these areas, and allows the President to extend, modify, or restrict the application of laws to these areas.

questions.question: Which amendment to the Constitution gave precedence to Directive Principles of State Policy over Fundamental Rights?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment Act, 1976 gave precedence to Directive Principles of State Policy over Fundamental Rights. This amendment inserted Article 31C, which provided that no law implementing the Directive Principles in Articles 39(b) and 39(c) could be invalidated on the grounds of violating Articles 14, 19, and 31. However, the Supreme Court in the Minerva Mills case (1980) struck down this provision as it violated the basic structure doctrine.

questions.question: The doctrine of 'Implied Powers' in the Indian Constitution relates to:

options.text: Inherent powers of the Supreme Court

questions.explanation: The doctrine of 'Implied Powers' in the Indian Constitution relates to inherent powers of the Supreme Court. Under Article 142, the Supreme Court has been empowered to pass any decree or order necessary for "complete justice" in any case. This has been interpreted to grant the Court certain implied powers beyond those explicitly mentioned in the Constitution, allowing it to issue innovative remedies and directions.

questions.question: Which of the following bodies is established by the Constitution itself?
questions.explanation: The Finance Commission is established by the Constitution itself under Article 280. It is a constitutional body appointed by the President every five years to recommend the distribution of tax proceeds between the Union and States and the principles governing grants-in-aid. The other bodies mentioned—Planning Commission (now replaced by NITI Aayog) and National Development Council—were created by executive resolutions and are not mentioned in the Constitution.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Indian Parliament is correct?

options.text: Rajya Sabha can be dissolved by the President on recommendation of the Prime Minister
A Money Bill can be introduced in either House of Parliament
Joint sitting of both Houses can be convened to resolve deadlocks on Money Bills
The Speaker of Lok Sabha is elected by both Houses of Parliament

questions.explanation: The statement "Joint sitting of both Houses can be convened to resolve deadlocks on Money Bills" is NOT correct about the Indian Parliament. Under Article 108, while joint sittings can be convened to resolve deadlocks on ordinary bills, Money Bills cannot be subjected to joint sittings as they must originate in Lok Sabha, and Rajya Sabha has limited powers to only recommend changes within 14 days.

questions.question: Which Amendment Act of the Constitution introduced changes to the Preamble?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment Act, 1976 introduced changes to the Preamble of the Constitution. This amendment, enacted during the Emergency period, added three new words to the Preamble: "SOCIALIST," "SECULAR," and "INTEGRITY." The original Preamble declared India as a "Sovereign Democratic Republic," which was changed to a "Sovereign Socialist Secular Democratic Republic," and "unity of the nation" was changed to "unity and integrity of the nation."

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Election Commission of India is correct?

options.text: It conducts elections only to the Parliament and State Legislatures
The Constitution originally provided for a multi-member Election Commission
The removal procedure for all Election Commissioners is the same
Election Commissioners have a fixed tenure of 5 years

questions.explanation: The statement "The removal procedure for all Election Commissioners is the same" is correct about the Election Commission of India. As per the Supreme Court's ruling in the T.N. Seshan case (1995), other Election Commissioners (ECs) have the same protection against removal as the Chief Election Commissioner (CEC). The CEC can be removed only through impeachment, and this protection extends to other ECs to ensure the body's independence.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT part of the 'Basic Structure' of the Constitution as propounded by the Supreme Court?
questions.explanation: Specific provisions regarding reservation is NOT part of the 'Basic Structure' of the Constitution as propounded by the Supreme Court. While the Supreme Court has identified several features as part of the basic structure (including the three mentioned in the other options), particular reservation provisions or percentages are not considered part of it. The principle of equality and affirmative action is part of the basic structure, but specific reservation details can be amended.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India: 1. The CAG is appointed by the President of India. 2. The CAG has the power to audit all receipts and expenditure of the Union and State governments. 3. The CAG has the power to audit the accounts of private companies. 4. The reports of the CAG are examined by the Public Accounts Committee. Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, and 4 are correct regarding the CAG. The CAG is appointed by the President (Article 148), audits receipts and expenditure of Union and State governments (Article 149), and CAG reports are examined by the Public Accounts Committee. Statement 3 is incorrect as the CAG traditionally does not have the power to directly audit private companies unless they are substantially financed by the government or involved in public-private partnerships.

questions.question: The Indian Constitution has borrowed the concept of Directive Principles of State Policy from which country's constitution?
questions.explanation: The Indian Constitution has borrowed the concept of Directive Principles of State Policy from the Constitution of Ireland (1937), which in turn was influenced by the Spanish Constitution. The Irish Constitution contained "Directive Principles of Social Policy" intended as guidelines for the Irish Parliament. The Indian Constituent Assembly adapted this concept to include a wide range of economic, social, and political principles as goals for the Indian state to achieve.

questions.question: The concept of 'Judicial Review' in the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from:
questions.explanation: The concept of 'Judicial Review' in the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from the United States of America. While not explicitly mentioned in the US Constitution, judicial review was established in the landmark case Marbury v. Madison (1803). In India, this concept is explicitly provided in Articles 13, 32, 131-136, 143, 226, and 246, empowering courts to examine the constitutionality of legislative and executive actions.

questions.question: Which of the following is a correct statement about the powers of the Rajya Sabha?

options.text: It has no power in the election of the President of India
It can disapprove or amend a Money Bill
It cannot initiate a constitutional amendment bill
It has no power in the removal of the Council of Ministers

questions.explanation: It has no power in the removal of the Council of Ministers is a correct statement about the powers of the Rajya Sabha. Under India's parliamentary system, the Council of Ministers is collectively responsible only to the Lok Sabha (Article 75), and a no-confidence motion can be moved only in the Lok Sabha, not in the Rajya Sabha. The other statements are incorrect, as Rajya Sabha participates in presidential elections, can recommend (not amend) changes to Money Bills, and can initiate constitutional amendments.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Fundamental Rights is NOT correct?

options.text: They are absolute and cannot be restricted
They are guaranteed against arbitrary state action
Some of them are available only to citizens while others are available to all persons

questions.explanation: The statement "They are absolute and cannot be restricted" is NOT correct about Fundamental Rights. Fundamental Rights in the Indian Constitution are not absolute and can be subject to reasonable restrictions. For example, Article 19 provides for six freedoms but also specifies grounds on which the state can impose reasonable restrictions. Similarly, other rights have built-in limitations or can be restricted during emergencies under Articles 352, 358, and 359.

questions.question: Which article of the Indian Constitution abolishes untouchability and forbids its practice in any form?
questions.explanation: Article 17 of the Indian Constitution abolishes untouchability and forbids its practice in any form. It states: "Untouchability is abolished and its practice in any form is forbidden. The enforcement of any disability arising out of untouchability shall be an offence punishable in accordance with law." This article directly addresses the historical social evil of untouchability and provides constitutional foundation for laws like the Protection of Civil Rights Act, 1955.

questions.question: The power to increase the number of judges in the Supreme Court of India rests with:
questions.explanation: The power to increase the number of judges in the Supreme Court of India rests with the Parliament. Under Article 124(1), the Constitution initially provided for 7 judges (1 Chief Justice and 6 other judges) but empowered Parliament to increase this number through legislation. Parliament has exercised this power multiple times, increasing the strength from the original 8 to the current 34 (including the Chief Justice) through amendments to the Supreme Court (Number of Judges) Act, 1956.

questions.question: Which part of the Indian Constitution deals with Fundamental Rights?
questions.explanation: Part III of the Indian Constitution (Articles 12-35) deals with Fundamental Rights. These include rights to equality (Articles 14-18), freedom (Articles 19-22), against exploitation (Articles 23-24), to freedom of religion (Articles 25-28), cultural and educational rights (Articles 29-30), and constitutional remedies (Articles 32-35). These rights are justiciable, and citizens can approach the Supreme Court or High Courts for their enforcement.

questions.question: Which of the following rights was removed from the list of Fundamental Rights by the 44th Amendment to the Constitution?
questions.explanation: The Right to Property was removed from the list of Fundamental Rights by the 44th Amendment to the Constitution in 1978. Previously existing as Article 31, it was shifted from Part III (Fundamental Rights) to Article 300A in Part XII, making it a legal right rather than a fundamental right. This change allowed the government to implement land reforms and redistribution policies without judicial interference.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Attorney General of India is NOT correct?

options.text: The Attorney General is appointed by the President of India
The Attorney General must have the same qualifications required for a Supreme Court Judge
The Attorney General is a member of the Union Cabinet
The Attorney General has the right to attend proceedings of both Houses of Parliament

questions.explanation: The statement "The Attorney General is a member of the Union Cabinet" is NOT correct. The Attorney General of India, appointed under Article 76, is the chief legal advisor to the Government of India and its primary lawyer in the Supreme Court, but is not a member of the Union Cabinet. This separation ensures independent legal advice to the government without political influence within the Cabinet.

questions.question: The term 'Federal' has been used in the Indian Constitution in which of the following parts?
questions.explanation: The term 'Federal' has not been used anywhere in the Indian Constitution. Although India has several federal features (division of powers, bicameralism, independent judiciary), the Constitution describes India as a "Union of States" in Article 1, deliberately avoiding the term "federation" or "federal." This omission reflects the drafters' intention to create a strong center with unitary features during emergencies.

questions.question: Which of the following High Courts has the jurisdiction over the largest number of states and union territories?
questions.explanation: The Gauhati High Court has jurisdiction over the largest number of states and union territories. Though its primary jurisdiction is Assam, it has benches in Nagaland, Mizoram, and Arunachal Pradesh. Historically, it also had jurisdiction over Manipur, Meghalaya, and Tripura before they established separate High Courts. This extensive jurisdiction was due to the reorganization of the northeastern states after independence.

questions.question: Under which article of the Constitution can the President of India refer a matter to the Supreme Court for its advisory opinion?
questions.explanation: Under Article 143 of the Constitution, the President of India can refer a matter to the Supreme Court for its advisory opinion. This provision allows the President to seek the Court's opinion on questions of law or fact that have arisen or are likely to arise and are of such public importance that it is expedient to obtain the Court's opinion. This power is discretionary for the Court, which may decline to express its opinion in certain cases.

questions.question: Which of the following combinations of Fundamental Rights and Fundamental Duties is correctly matched?

options.text: Right to Equality – To value and preserve rich heritage of our composite culture
Right to Freedom – To abide by the Constitution and respect its ideals and institutions
Right against Exploitation – To defend the country and render national service when called upon to do so
Right to Freedom of Religion – To develop scientific temper, humanism, spirit of inquiry and reform

questions.explanation: The combination "Right to Equality – To value and preserve rich heritage of our composite culture" is correctly matched. While there isn't a direct one-to-one correlation between specific Fundamental Rights (Articles 14-35) and Fundamental Duties (Article 51A), preserving India's composite culture (duty under Article 51A(f)) aligns with the principles of equality (Articles 14-18) by respecting diversity and cultural pluralism without discrimination.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Indian federal system is correct?

options.text: The Governor of a state is appointed by the President but can be removed by the state legislature
The state government has exclusive power to levy income tax on agricultural income
Parliament has no power to make laws on state subjects even during a national emergency
In case of inconsistency between Union and State laws on a concurrent subject, the State law prevails

questions.explanation: The statement "The state government has exclusive power to levy income tax on agricultural income" is correct about the Indian federal system. Entry 46 in List II (State List) of the Seventh Schedule gives states exclusive power to tax agricultural income. The other statements are incorrect: Governors are appointed and removed by the President; Parliament can legislate on state subjects during national emergency; and in case of inconsistency between Union and State laws on concurrent subjects, the Union law generally prevails.

questions.question: The Electoral College for election of the President of India consists of:

options.text: All members of Parliament and State Legislatures
Elected members of both Houses of Parliament and elected members of State Legislative Assemblies
All members of Rajya Sabha and elected members of Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies
Elected members of both Houses of Parliament only

questions.explanation: The Electoral College for election of the President of India consists of elected members of both Houses of Parliament and elected members of State Legislative Assemblies. Article 54 provides that the President shall be elected by members of an electoral college consisting of: (1) elected members of both Houses of Parliament; and (2) elected members of the Legislative Assemblies of the States (including NCT of Delhi and Puducherry). Nominated members do not participate.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the office of 'Whip' in the parliamentary system: 1. It is mentioned in the Constitution of India 2. They are appointed by the political parties 3. They ensure discipline among party members in the Parliament 4. Chief Whip is a minister in the government Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 2 and 3 are correct about the office of 'Whip' in the parliamentary system. Whips are appointed by political parties (not constitutional functionaries) and ensure discipline among party members in Parliament by ensuring attendance and voting according to party lines. Statements 1 and 4 are incorrect: the office of Whip is not mentioned in the Constitution but is based on parliamentary conventions; and while in some countries the Chief Whip may be a minister, this is not universally true in India.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Preamble to the Indian Constitution is NOT correct?

options.text: It has been described as the 'Identity Card' of the Constitution
It is a part of the Basic Structure of the Constitution
It can be amended by Parliament under Article 368
It can override specific provisions of the Constitution in case of inconsistency

questions.explanation: The statement "It can override specific provisions of the Constitution in case of inconsistency" is NOT correct about the Preamble. While the Preamble is an important interpretative tool and part of the Constitution's basic structure (Kesavananda Bharati case, 1973), it cannot override or invalidate specific constitutional provisions. It serves as a guiding principle for interpreting ambiguous provisions but cannot be used to strike down explicit constitutional provisions.

questions.question: The Constitution of India was enacted by a Constituent Assembly set up under:
questions.explanation: The Constitution of India was enacted by a Constituent Assembly set up under the Cabinet Mission Plan, 1946. The Plan, announced on May 16, 1946, provided for the formation of a constitution-making body through indirect election by members of the provincial assemblies. Despite the partition of India, the Constituent Assembly continued its work and adopted the Constitution on November 26, 1949, which came into effect on January 26, 1950.

questions.question: Which of the following Articles of the Indian Constitution has been described as the 'Heart and Soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar?
questions.explanation: Article 32 of the Indian Constitution has been described as the 'Heart and Soul' of the Constitution by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar. This article guarantees the right to constitutional remedies, empowering citizens to approach the Supreme Court directly for enforcement of their fundamental rights. It authorizes the Supreme Court to issue directions, orders, or writs, including habeas corpus, mandamus, prohibition, quo warranto, and certiorari for the enforcement of rights conferred by Part III.

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding Money Bills: 1. A Money Bill can be introduced only in the Lok Sabha 2. The Rajya Sabha cannot reject or amend a Money Bill 3. The Speaker's decision on whether a bill is a Money Bill is final 4. Joint sitting of both Houses can be convened to resolve deadlock over a Money Bill Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct regarding Money Bills. Under Article 109, a Money Bill can be introduced only in Lok Sabha; the Rajya Sabha can only make recommendations (not amendments) within 14 days, which Lok Sabha may accept or reject; and the Speaker's certification of a bill as a Money Bill is final. Statement 4 is incorrect because joint sitting provisions under Article 108 do not apply to Money Bills, as Rajya Sabha doesn't have the power to reject or amend them.

questions.question: The Constitution describes India as:
questions.explanation: The Constitution describes India as "a Union of States" in Article 1. The term "Union" was deliberately chosen over "Federation" to emphasize the indestructible nature of the Indian Union, indicating that states do not have the right to secede. As Dr. B.R. Ambedkar explained during Constituent Assembly debates, "The Federation is a Union because it is indestructible. Though the country and the people may be divided into different states for convenience of administration, the country is one integral whole."

questions.question: Who presided over the first meeting of the Indian Constituent Assembly?
questions.explanation: Sachchidananda Sinha presided over the first meeting of the Indian Constituent Assembly held on December 9, 1946, as the temporary Chairman (President). As the oldest member of the Assembly, he was chosen to chair the first sitting. Later, Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as the permanent Chairman (President) of the Constituent Assembly on December 11, 1946, and continued in this role throughout the constitution-making process.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the Vice-President of India is correct?

options.text: He is elected by members of both Houses of Parliament
His election can be challenged in the Supreme Court
He must have the same qualifications as required for a member of the Rajya Sabha
He serves as the ex-officio Chairman of the NITI Aayog

questions.explanation: The statement "He is elected by members of both Houses of Parliament" is correct regarding the Vice-President of India. Under Article 66, the Vice-President is elected by members of an electoral college consisting of members of both Houses of Parliament (Lok Sabha and Rajya Sabha) in accordance with proportional representation by means of a single transferable vote through secret ballot, unlike the President's election which also includes state legislators.

questions.question: Which Constitutional Amendment Act reduced the voting age from 21 to 18 years?
questions.explanation: The 61st Constitutional Amendment Act, 1988 reduced the voting age from 21 to 18 years. This amendment modified Article 326 of the Constitution to provide that elections to the Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies would be based on adult suffrage with the voting age as 18 years instead of 21 years. The amendment aimed to give youth a greater voice in the democratic process.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT included as a fundamental duty in the Indian Constitution?

options.text: To respect the National Flag and National Anthem
To protect and improve the natural environment
To pay taxes honestly and punctually

questions.explanation: To pay taxes honestly and punctually is NOT included as a fundamental duty in the Indian Constitution. The 11 fundamental duties enumerated in Article 51A (added by the 42nd Amendment in 1976 and expanded by the 86th Amendment in 2002) include respect for national symbols, environmental protection, and safeguarding public property, but do not explicitly mention tax payment, though it could be implied under "abiding by the Constitution and respecting its ideals."

questions.question: Which one of the following was NOT a feature of the Government of India Act, 1935?
questions.explanation: Universal adult franchise was NOT a feature of the Government of India Act, 1935. The Act maintained a limited franchise based on property, taxation, education, and other qualifications, restricting voting rights to about 14% of the adult population. The other features—provincial autonomy (ending dyarchy in provinces), dyarchy at the center (though never implemented), and establishment of a Federal Court (precursor to the Supreme Court)—were all part of the 1935 Act.

questions.question: The term "socialist" was added to the Preamble of the Indian Constitution by which Constitutional Amendment?
questions.explanation: The term "socialist" was added to the Preamble of the Indian Constitution by the 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976. This amendment, enacted during the Emergency period under Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, added three new words to the Preamble: "SOCIALIST," "SECULAR," and "INTEGRITY." The original Preamble declared India as a "Sovereign Democratic Republic," which was changed to a "Sovereign Socialist Secular Democratic Republic."

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Anti-Defection Law is NOT correct?

options.text: It was inserted by the 52nd Amendment Act, 1985
A member can be disqualified if he votes against the party whip in a confidence motion
The Speaker/Chairman of the House decides on disqualification
The law applies only to state legislatures and not to Parliament

questions.explanation: The statement "The law applies only to state legislatures and not to Parliament" is NOT correct about the Anti-Defection Law. The law, contained in the Tenth Schedule of the Constitution (added by the 52nd Amendment Act, 1985), applies to both Parliament and state legislatures. It provides for disqualification of elected members for defection (switching parties), with the presiding officer (Speaker/Chairman) deciding such cases.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Financial Emergency under Article 360: 1. It can be proclaimed by the President if financial stability of India is threatened 2. It requires parliamentary approval within two months 3. It can reduce the salaries of Supreme Court and High Court judges 4. No Financial Emergency has ever been proclaimed in India Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, and 4 are correct about Financial Emergency under Article 360. The President can proclaim it if financial stability is threatened; it can lead to reduction of salaries including judges of Supreme Court and High Courts; and no Financial Emergency has ever been proclaimed in India. Statement 2 is incorrect because Financial Emergency must be approved by Parliament within one month, not two months.

questions.question: Which of the following bodies/offices is NOT mentioned in the original Constitution of India?
questions.explanation: The Planning Commission is NOT mentioned in the original Constitution of India. It was established in March 1950 by a resolution of the Government of India as a non-constitutional, non-statutory body. The other bodies—Finance Commission (Article 280), Election Commission (Article 324), and Union Public Service Commission (Article 315)—are all explicitly provided for in the original Constitution of India adopted in 1949.

questions.question: Which of the following Parliamentary committees in India is chaired by a member of the Opposition party by convention?
questions.explanation: The Public Accounts Committee (PAC) is chaired by a member of the Opposition party by convention (though not by constitutional requirement). This tradition began in 1967 and aims to ensure impartial scrutiny of government expenditure. The PAC examines the audit reports of the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) after they are presented to Parliament and ensures accountability in the use of public funds.

questions.question: Who among the following described the Directive Principles of State Policy as "novel features" of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: Granville Austin, a prominent American historian and scholar of the Indian Constitution, described the Directive Principles of State Policy as "novel features" of the Indian Constitution in his acclaimed work "The Indian Constitution: Cornerstone of a Nation" (1966). He viewed the Directive Principles as an innovative aspect that reflected the social and economic goals of the nationalist movement and formed a "conscience of the Constitution."

questions.question: Which of the following cases is related to the 'Basic Structure Doctrine'?

options.text: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
Maneka Gandhi v. Union of India

questions.explanation: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973) is related to the 'Basic Structure Doctrine.' In this landmark case, a 13-judge bench of the Supreme Court (by a 7:6 majority) propounded that while Parliament has the power to amend any part of the Constitution, it cannot alter or destroy its basic structure or framework. This doctrine has since served as a limitation on Parliament's amending power and protected the Constitution's essential features.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Union Territories in India is correct?

options.text: All Union Territories have their own legislatures
The President of India administers the Union Territories through an Administrator appointed by him
All Union Territories send representatives to both houses of Parliament
Union Territories are constitutionally at par with States

questions.explanation: The statement "The President of India administers the Union Territories through an Administrator appointed by him" is correct. Under Article 239, every Union Territory is administered by the President acting through an Administrator (designated as Lieutenant Governor or Administrator) appointed by him. The degree of presidential control varies, with some UTs having legislatures and others being directly governed by the central government.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a condition for a political party to be recognized as a 'National Party' by the Election Commission of India?

options.text: Winning 2% of seats in the Lok Sabha from at least three different states
Securing at least 6% of valid votes in four or more states and winning at least four Lok Sabha seats
Recognition as a state party in at least four states
Winning at least 8% of the total valid votes in the last general election

questions.explanation: Recognition as a state party in at least four states is NOT a condition for a political party to be recognized as a 'National Party' by the Election Commission. According to the Election Symbols (Reservation and Allotment) Order, 1968, as amended, a party can be recognized as a National Party if it fulfills any of these conditions: winning 2% Lok Sabha seats from at least 3 states; securing 6% votes in 4 states plus 4 Lok Sabha seats; or being recognized in 4 states (not merely being a state party).

questions.question: Which among the following is regarded as the main watchdog for ensuring fiscal discipline at the state level?
questions.explanation: The Finance Commission is regarded as the main watchdog for ensuring fiscal discipline at the state level. Established under Article 280 of the Constitution, it recommends the principles governing grants-in-aid and the distribution of tax revenues between the Union and states. It plays a crucial role in promoting fiscal discipline by setting conditions for states to access funds and recommending measures for sound finances.

questions.question: Which of the following writs is issued by a court to inquire by what authority a person holds a public office?
questions.explanation: The writ of Quo Warranto (which means "by what authority") is issued by a court to inquire by what authority a person holds a public office. It is used to challenge the legality of a person's appointment to a public office. This writ helps prevent illegal usurpation of public offices by challenging the incumbent's legal right to hold that position if their appointment appears to violate established rules.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Special Officer for Linguistic Minorities: 1. The post was created under Article 350B of the Constitution 2. The Officer is appointed by the President of India 3. The Officer reports to the Parliament 4. The Officer investigates matters relating to linguistic minorities Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, and 4 are correct. The Special Officer for Linguistic Minorities was created under Article 350B (added by the 7th Amendment); is appointed by the President; and investigates matters relating to linguistic minorities. Statement 3 is incorrect because the Officer reports to the President, not directly to Parliament (though reports are laid before Parliament by the Ministry of Minority Affairs).

questions.question: Which of the following Constitutional Amendments is known as the 'Mini Constitution' due to the extensive changes it made?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Constitutional Amendment Act, 1976 is known as the 'Mini Constitution' due to the extensive changes it made to the Constitution. Passed during the Emergency period, it made wide-ranging amendments to the Preamble, Fundamental Rights, Directive Principles, and nearly 50 articles of the Constitution. It added words like "socialist," "secular," and "integrity" to the Preamble, strengthened Parliament's amending powers, and limited judicial review.

questions.question: Which among the following is NOT a Directive Principle of State Policy in the Indian Constitution?

options.text: Promotion of international peace and security
Equal pay for equal work for men and women

questions.explanation: Equal opportunities for all citizens is NOT a Directive Principle of State Policy in the Indian Constitution. It is a Fundamental Right under Article 16 (equality of opportunity in matters of public employment). The other options are all Directive Principles: promotion of international peace (Article 51), equal pay for equal work (Article 39(d)), and separation of judiciary from executive (Article 50).

questions.question: The Sharda Act, 1929 is related to:
questions.explanation: The Sharda Act, 1929 (officially called the Child Marriage Restraint Act) is related to prohibition of child marriage. Named after its sponsor Harbilas Sarda, it fixed the minimum age of marriage at 14 for girls and 18 for boys. Though passed before independence, it was consistent with Article 39(f) of the Directive Principles which directs the state to ensure that children develop in a healthy manner and are protected from exploitation.

questions.question: For a citizen of India, which of the following is a Fundamental Duty but NOT a Fundamental Right?

options.text: To defend the country when called upon

questions.explanation: To defend the country when called upon is a Fundamental Duty (Article 51A(d)) but NOT a Fundamental Right. The Constitution makes it a duty for citizens to defend the country and render national service when called upon, but there is no corresponding fundamental right. In contrast, freedom of speech (Article 19), freedom of religion (Article 25), and right to constitutional remedies (Article 32) are all Fundamental Rights.

questions.question: Which one of the following schedules of the Indian Constitution deals with the allocation of seats in the Rajya Sabha to various states?
questions.explanation: The Fourth Schedule of the Indian Constitution deals with the allocation of seats in the Rajya Sabha to various states and Union Territories. This schedule provides for the specific number of seats assigned to each state and UT in the Council of States (Rajya Sabha), determined principally on the basis of population, ensuring proportional representation in the upper house of Parliament.

questions.question: Which of the following bodies is NOT mentioned in the Constitution of India?
questions.explanation: All of the above bodies—Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI), Central Vigilance Commission (CVC), and National Human Rights Commission (NHRC)—are NOT mentioned in the Constitution of India. They are statutory bodies created by acts of Parliament: CBI under the Delhi Special Police Establishment Act, CVC under the Central Vigilance Commission Act, and NHRC under the Protection of Human Rights Act.

questions.question: Which of the following Constitutional Amendments made education a Fundamental Right?
questions.explanation: The 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002 made education a Fundamental Right. This amendment inserted Article 21A into the Constitution, making education for children aged 6-14 years a fundamental right. It also amended Article 45 (to provide for early childhood care and education for children below 6 years) and added a new fundamental duty under Article 51A(k) for parents/guardians to provide education to their children.

questions.question: Which of the following committees recommended the inclusion of Fundamental Duties in the Constitution?
questions.explanation: The Swaran Singh Committee recommended the inclusion of Fundamental Duties in the Constitution. This committee was constituted during the Emergency period in 1975, and based on its recommendations, the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976 added a new Part IVA (Article 51A) to the Constitution, prescribing 10 Fundamental Duties for citizens. Later, an 11th duty was added by the 86th Amendment Act, 2002.

questions.question: With reference to the appointment of Supreme Court judges, consider the following statements: 1. The judges are appointed by the President in consultation with the Chief Justice of India 2. The Collegium system is mentioned in the Constitution 3. The President can return the recommendations for reconsideration once 4. The Second Judges Case (1993) established the Collegium system Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, and 4 are correct. Judges are appointed by the President in consultation with the CJI (Article 124); the President can return recommendations once for reconsideration; and the Second Judges Case (Supreme Court Advocates-on-Record Association v. Union of India, 1993) established the Collegium system. Statement 2 is incorrect as the Collegium system is not mentioned in the Constitution but was created through judicial interpretation.

questions.question: The Constituent Assembly that framed the Constitution of India was set up under:
questions.explanation: The Constituent Assembly that framed the Constitution of India was set up under the Cabinet Mission Plan, 1946. The Plan, proposed by a three-member mission sent by the British government to India in March 1946, outlined the framework for the composition and functioning of the Constituent Assembly. Elections to the Assembly were held in July 1946, and its first meeting was convened on December 9, 1946.

questions.question: With reference to the Proclamation of Emergency under Article 352, which of the following statements is NOT correct?

options.text: It must be approved by both Houses of Parliament within one month
It can be issued on grounds of war, external aggression, or armed rebellion
It can be revoked by the President at any time without Parliamentary approval
It automatically suspends all Fundamental Rights under Part III

questions.explanation: The statement "It automatically suspends all Fundamental Rights under Part III" is NOT correct regarding Emergency under Article 352. Only Articles 19 (six freedoms) and in some cases Article 21 (right to life and personal liberty) can be suspended during Emergency, and that too only by specific Presidential Orders under Article 359. Other Fundamental Rights, such as equality before law, freedom of religion, etc., remain enforceable even during Emergency.

questions.question: The concept of 'Directive Principles of State Policy' was borrowed from which Constitution?
questions.explanation: The concept of 'Directive Principles of State Policy' was borrowed from the Irish Constitution of 1937. The Irish Constitution contained a similar set of principles called "Directive Principles of Social Policy," which themselves were influenced by the Spanish Constitution. The Indian Constitution adapted this concept to include a wide range of economic, social, and political principles as non-justiciable guidelines for the state to achieve.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the State Election Commission is correct?

options.text: It conducts elections to Parliament and State Legislatures
It is appointed by the Governor of the state
Its independence is ensured through constitutional provisions
It is a multi-member body in all states

questions.explanation: The statement "Its independence is ensured through constitutional provisions" is correct about the State Election Commission. Under Article 243K, the State Election Commissioner can only be removed in the same manner as a High Court Judge, ensuring independence. Other statements are incorrect: it conducts elections to Panchayats and Municipalities (not Parliament/State Legislatures); it has a single commissioner (not multi-member); and while appointed by the Governor, conditions of service cannot be varied to their disadvantage after appointment.

questions.question: Which part of the Indian Constitution deals with services under the Union and the States?
questions.explanation: Part XIV of the Indian Constitution deals with services under the Union and the States. Articles 308 to 323 in this part contain provisions relating to recruitment, conditions of service, protection, and requirements for civil servants at both Union and State levels. It establishes the Union Public Service Commission and State Public Service Commissions and provides for independent functioning of these bodies to ensure fair recruitment to public services.

questions.question: The resolution for removing the Vice-President of India can be moved in:

options.text: Joint sitting of both Houses of Parliament

questions.explanation: The resolution for removing the Vice-President of India can be moved in the Rajya Sabha only. According to Article 67(b), the Vice-President can be removed by a resolution passed by a majority of all the members of the Rajya Sabha and agreed to by the Lok Sabha. Since the Vice-President serves as the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha, the resolution for removal must originate in that House.

questions.question: Which of the following High Courts has the distinction of having jurisdiction over three states?
questions.explanation: The Punjab and Haryana High Court has the distinction of having jurisdiction over three entities: the states of Punjab and Haryana, and the Union Territory of Chandigarh. Located in Chandigarh, it serves as the common High Court for these two states and the UT. The Gauhati High Court previously had jurisdiction over multiple northeastern states, but after the establishment of separate High Courts for some of these states, it now primarily serves Assam.

questions.question: With reference to the provisions of the Anti-Defection Law, which of the following is NOT a ground for disqualification?

options.text: If an elected member voluntarily gives up membership of his political party
If a nominated member joins a political party after six months of nomination
If an elected member votes against the party directive on a confidence motion
If an elected member criticizes party policies outside the legislature

questions.explanation: If an elected member criticizes party policies outside the legislature is NOT a ground for disqualification under the Anti-Defection Law (10th Schedule). Members can express dissent outside parliament/legislature without risking disqualification. The law only penalizes: voluntarily giving up party membership, voting against party directives on certain motions (confidence/no-confidence, money bills, etc.), and independent members joining parties. Nominated members have six months to join parties without disqualification.

questions.question: Which of the following rights is NOT available to foreigners in India?

options.text: Right to life and personal liberty
Right to freedom of speech and profession

questions.explanation: The "Right to freedom of speech and profession" under Article 19 is NOT available to foreigners in India. Article 19 explicitly begins with "All citizens shall have the right..." and applies only to Indian citizens. Foreigners in India do enjoy other fundamental rights that are available to "any person" or "all persons," such as equality before law (Article 14), life and personal liberty (Article 21), and freedom of religion (Articles 25-28).

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Freedom of Religion in India is NOT correct?

options.text: The state cannot impose religious tax on any particular religion
The state cannot establish official religion
The state cannot interfere in religious practices even if they violate public health
Every religious denomination has the right to establish religious institutions
