Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was its President
It adopted the Constitution on January 26, 1950

questions.explanation: The statement "Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was its President" is NOT correct about the Constituent Assembly of India. Dr. Rajendra Prasad served as the President (Chairman) of the Constituent Assembly, while Dr. B.R. Ambedkar was the Chairman of the Drafting Committee, not the President of the entire Assembly. The other statements are also incorrect: it was established under Cabinet Mission Plan 1946, had indirectly elected members, and adopted the Constitution on November 26, 1949.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Inter-State Council is NOT correct?

options.text: It is a constitutional body established under Article 263
It investigates and discusses subjects of common interest between states
It makes recommendations for better coordination of policy and action
It is a permanent body that meets regularly

questions.explanation: The statement "It is a permanent body that meets regularly" is NOT correct about the Inter-State Council. While established under Article 263, it is not a permanent body with regular meetings but is convened as and when needed by the President. It was set up in 1990 based on Sarkaria Commission recommendations but meets irregularly. Its last meeting before 2016 was in 2006, demonstrating the ad hoc nature of its functioning.

questions.question: The 'Doctrine of Implied Powers' in the Indian Constitution is associated with:

options.text: Powers of the President during emergency
Powers of the Supreme Court under Article 142
Administrative powers of the Prime Minister

questions.explanation: The 'Doctrine of Implied Powers' in the Indian Constitution is associated with powers of the Supreme Court under Article 142. This article empowers the Supreme Court to "make such order as is necessary for doing complete justice" in any case before it. Through judicial interpretation, this has evolved into the doctrine of implied powers, allowing the Court to issue directions and orders beyond those explicitly mentioned elsewhere in the Constitution.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT included in the Right to Freedom of Religion in the Indian Constitution?

options.text: Right to convert others to one's religion

questions.explanation: Right to convert others to one's religion is NOT explicitly included in the Right to Freedom of Religion in the Indian Constitution. While Articles 25-28 protect freedom of conscience, right to profess/practice religion, and right to establish religious institutions, the right to proselytize or convert others is subject to interpretation. The Supreme Court in Rev. Stainislaus v. State of Madhya Pradesh (1977) held that right to propagate religion doesn't include right to convert others.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a unitary feature of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: Strong Centre is NOT a unitary feature of the Indian Constitution but rather a federal feature with unitary bias. A strong Center is characteristic of India's particular federal arrangement, where the Union has greater powers than states. The other options are unitary features: single citizenship (unlike dual citizenship in some federations), integrated judiciary (single hierarchy with Supreme Court at apex), and independent judiciary (a feature of both unitary and federal systems).

questions.question: Who among the following has the authority to issue ordinances when the state legislature is not in session?

options.text: Chief Justice of the High Court

questions.explanation: The Governor of the state has the authority to issue ordinances when the state legislature is not in session. Under Article 213, the Governor can promulgate ordinances during recess of the legislature if circumstances exist that require immediate action. These ordinances have the same force as acts of the legislature but must be laid before the legislature when it reassembles and cease to operate six weeks after the legislature's reassembly.

questions.question: The power to determine the number of judges in a High Court rests with:
questions.explanation: The power to determine the number of judges in a High Court rests with the Parliament. Article 216 of the Constitution states that every High Court shall consist of a Chief Justice and such other judges as the President may from time to time appoint. While the President makes appointments, the Parliament through legislation determines the maximum number of judges in each High Court based on workload and other factors.

questions.question: Which of the following Parliamentary Committees examines the report of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India?
questions.explanation: The Public Accounts Committee examines the report of the Comptroller and Auditor General of India. This parliamentary committee, consisting of members from both houses, scrutinizes the appropriation accounts and the CAG's audit reports to ensure that public money is spent as authorized by Parliament. By convention, the PAC is chaired by a member of the opposition party to ensure objective scrutiny of government expenditure.

questions.question: The 'Judicial Review' power of the Supreme Court is derived from which of the following Articles of the Constitution?
questions.explanation: The 'Judicial Review' power of the Supreme Court is primarily derived from Article 13 of the Constitution. This article explicitly states that laws inconsistent with or in derogation of fundamental rights shall be void to the extent of inconsistency, empowering courts to review legislation for constitutional validity. While Articles 32, 131, and 142 also contribute to judicial review power, Article 13 is the foundational provision establishing this power.

questions.question: The President of India is elected through a system of:

options.text: Proportional representation by means of single transferable vote
Electoral college with equal representation from all states

questions.explanation: The President of India is elected through a system of proportional representation by means of single transferable vote. Article 55(3) of the Constitution explicitly states that "The election of the President shall be held in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote and the voting at such election shall be by secret ballot." This system ensures fair representation in the presidential electoral process.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a feature of a federal government?
questions.explanation: Single citizenship is NOT a feature of a federal government. In fact, many classic federations like the US have dual citizenship (state and national). Single citizenship is a unitary feature in India's federal system. The other options—written Constitution, independent judiciary, and division of powers—are essential features of federalism, providing the constitutional framework, adjudication mechanism for federal disputes, and distribution of authority between levels of government.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a feature of the parliamentary form of government?

options.text: Presence of a nominal head of state and a real head of government
Separation of powers between executive and legislature
Collective responsibility of the executive to the legislature
Membership of ministers in the legislature

questions.explanation: Separation of powers between executive and legislature is NOT a feature of the parliamentary form of government. Parliamentary systems feature fusion of executive and legislature, with ministers typically being members of Parliament. The other options are parliamentary features: dual executive (nominal head like President and real head like Prime Minister), collective responsibility of Cabinet to legislature, and ministers being members of the legislature (though with some exceptions possible).

questions.question: Which of the following writs is issued by a higher court to a lower court or tribunal to prevent it from exceeding its jurisdiction or acting contrary to the rules of natural justice?
questions.explanation: The writ of Prohibition is issued by a higher court to a lower court or tribunal to prevent it from exceeding its jurisdiction or acting contrary to the rules of natural justice. This writ literally means "to forbid" and is preventive in nature, used to stop a lower court from proceeding further with a case outside its jurisdiction. It differs from certiorari, which is issued after a decision has been made.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Rajya Sabha is correct?

options.text: It can be dissolved by the President on the recommendation of the Prime Minister
It has equal powers with the Lok Sabha in money matters
It has equal powers with the Lok Sabha in amending the Constitution
It can initiate bills for the formation of new states

questions.explanation: The statement "It has equal powers with the Lok Sabha in amending the Constitution" is correct about the Rajya Sabha. Under Article 368, constitutional amendments require special majority in both Houses of Parliament. The other statements are incorrect: Rajya Sabha is a permanent house that cannot be dissolved; it has limited powers in money matters; and while it can initiate bills for state formation, this isn't unique to Rajya Sabha as Lok Sabha can also initiate such bills.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the 'rule of law' in India is NOT correct?

options.text: All are equal before the law
No person shall be deprived of life or personal liberty except according to procedure established by law
Law is above all including the government
There can be no punishment without a specific law

questions.explanation: The statement "All are equal before the law" is NOT entirely correct about the 'rule of law' in India because certain constitutional and statutory provisions create exceptions. For instance, Article 361 provides immunity to the President and Governors from criminal proceedings during their term; foreign diplomats have immunity; and special provisions exist for certain groups under Articles 15(4) and 16(4). These create legitimate exceptions to complete equality before law.

questions.question: The 'Objective Resolution', which laid down the philosophy and fundamental values of the Constitution, was moved in the Constituent Assembly by:
questions.explanation: The 'Objective Resolution', which laid down the philosophy and fundamental values of the Constitution, was moved in the Constituent Assembly by Jawaharlal Nehru on December 13, 1946. This historic resolution outlined the objectives of the Constitution and was later adopted on January 22, 1947. It became the basis for the Preamble and provided guiding principles for the drafting of the Constitution.

questions.question: Which of the following is a political emergency provided in the Indian Constitution?

options.text: Emergency due to war or external aggression
Emergency due to failure of constitutional machinery in states
Emergency due to threat to financial stability

questions.explanation: Emergency due to failure of constitutional machinery in states (Article 356) is a political emergency provided in the Indian Constitution. Commonly known as "President's Rule," it can be proclaimed if the President, on Governor's report, is satisfied that the government of a state cannot be carried on in accordance with the constitutional provisions. This is distinct from national emergency (Article 352) or financial emergency (Article 360).

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Panchayati Raj System: 1. The 73rd Amendment Act made a three-tier Panchayati Raj System mandatory for all states 2. Elections to Panchayats are conducted by the State Election Commission 3. No reservation is provided for women in Panchayats 4. Panchayats have no financial powers Which statements are INCORRECT?
questions.explanation: Statements 3 and 4 are INCORRECT about the Panchayati Raj System. The 73rd Amendment mandates at least one-third reservation for women in Panchayats (now increased to 50% in many states), and Panchayats do have financial powers including authority to levy/collect taxes and prepare budgets. Statements 1 and 2 are correct: three-tier system is mandatory for states with population above 20 lakh, and State Election Commissions conduct Panchayat elections.

questions.question: Which of the following High Courts has the jurisdiction over the largest territory in India?
questions.explanation: The Allahabad High Court has jurisdiction over the largest territory in India. It serves Uttar Pradesh, which is India's most populous state and fourth largest state by area. Though the Gauhati High Court once had jurisdiction over multiple northeastern states, after the establishment of separate High Courts for many of these states, its territorial jurisdiction has reduced. Allahabad High Court, with its principal seat at Allahabad and a bench at Lucknow, remains the largest by territorial jurisdiction.

questions.question: Consider the following statements regarding the Rajya Sabha: 1. It is a permanent House and is not subject to dissolution 2. One-third of its members retire every two years 3. Its members are directly elected by people 4. It has special powers in creating All India Services Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, and 4 are correct regarding the Rajya Sabha. It is a permanent House not subject to dissolution; one-third of its members retire every two years; and it has special powers to create new All India Services under Article 312 by two-thirds majority resolution. Statement 3 is incorrect as Rajya Sabha members are indirectly elected by elected members of State Legislative Assemblies through proportional representation by single transferable vote—not directly by people.

questions.question: The Constitution of India originally classified the states as:

options.text: A, B, C and D categories
Part A, Part B, Part C and Part D states

questions.explanation: The Constitution of India originally classified the states as Part A, Part B, Part C and Part D states. Part A states were former governors' provinces of British India; Part B states were former princely states governed by rajpramukhs; Part C states were former chief commissioners' provinces and princely states; and Part D consisted only of the Andaman and Nicobar Islands. This classification was abolished by the 7th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1956.

questions.question: Which of the following bodies helps in maintaining the federal balance in India?
questions.explanation: The Finance Commission helps in maintaining the federal balance in India. Established under Article 280, it recommends the distribution of tax revenues between the Union and States and the principles governing grants-in-aid to States. This constitutional body ensures equitable distribution of financial resources, addressing vertical and horizontal imbalances in the federal system and preventing excessive centralization of fiscal powers.

questions.question: Which of the following Constitutional Amendments introduced changes in the Ninth Schedule of the Constitution?
questions.explanation: The First Constitutional Amendment Act, 1951 introduced changes in the Ninth Schedule of the Constitution. In fact, this amendment created the Ninth Schedule itself to protect certain land reform laws from judicial scrutiny. It was inserted after Article 31 to place land reform laws enacted by states beyond judicial review, even if they violated fundamental rights. Subsequently, many amendments have added more laws to this schedule.

questions.question: In which case did the Supreme Court rule that the Preamble is part of the Constitution?

options.text: A.K. Gopalan v. State of Madras
Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Minerva Mills v. Union of India

questions.explanation: In Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973), the Supreme Court ruled that the Preamble is part of the Constitution. This landmark judgment overruled the earlier view expressed in the Berubari Union case (1960) that the Preamble was not part of the Constitution. The Court in Kesavananda Bharati held that the Preamble indicates the basic structure of the Constitution, which cannot be amended under Article 368.

questions.question: Which of the following rights was described by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar as the "heart and soul of the Constitution"?

options.text: Right to Life and Personal Liberty (Article 21)

questions.explanation: The Right to Constitutional Remedies (Article 32) was described by Dr. B.R. Ambedkar as the "heart and soul of the Constitution." During Constituent Assembly debates, he emphasized that Article 32, which guarantees the right to move the Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamental rights, was the most important article without which the Constitution would be meaningless. This right provides citizens with direct remedy when their fundamental rights are violated.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a function of the Union Public Service Commission?

options.text: Conducting examinations for appointments to All-India Services
Advising on matters referred by the President
Serving as a disciplinary authority for All-India Services officers
Making recruitment to civil service posts

questions.explanation: Serving as a disciplinary authority for All-India Services officers is NOT a function of the Union Public Service Commission. Disciplinary authority for these officers rests with the government, with UPSC providing only consultation on disciplinary matters. The UPSC conducts examinations for civil services recruitment, makes direct recruitment to certain posts, and advises the President on civil service matters, but does not itself exercise disciplinary authority over service members.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a constitutional body?
questions.explanation: The Central Information Commission is NOT a constitutional body. It was established under the Right to Information Act, 2005, making it a statutory body. The other options—Election Commission (Article 324), National Commission for Scheduled Castes (Article 338), and Union Public Service Commission (Article 315)—are all explicitly provided for in specific articles of the Constitution and are considered constitutional bodies.

questions.question: Regarding Money Bills, consider the following statements: 1. A Money Bill can be introduced only in the Lok Sabha 2. The Rajya Sabha can reject a Money Bill 3. The President can withhold assent to a Money Bill 4. A Money Bill can be introduced only on the recommendation of the President Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 3, and 4 are correct regarding Money Bills. Under Articles 109, 110, and 117, Money Bills can be introduced only in Lok Sabha, only on President's recommendation, and the President can withhold assent (though rarely done). Statement 2 is incorrect because Rajya Sabha cannot reject Money Bills—it can only make recommendations within 14 days, which Lok Sabha may accept or reject. If Rajya Sabha doesn't return the bill within 14 days, it's deemed passed.

questions.question: Which Constitutional Amendment abolished the Right to Property as a Fundamental Right?
questions.explanation: The 44th Constitutional Amendment Act, 1978 abolished the Right to Property as a Fundamental Right. This amendment deleted Article 19(1)(f) and Article 31 from Part III (Fundamental Rights) and added Article 300A to Part XII, making the right to property a constitutional right rather than a fundamental right. This change allowed the government greater flexibility in implementing land reform measures by reducing judicial intervention in property acquisition cases.

questions.question: Which of the following pairs of Articles and their subject matter is NOT correctly matched?

options.text: Article 21 - Protection of Life and Personal Liberty

questions.explanation: The pair "Article 32 - Abolition of Untouchability" is NOT correctly matched. Article 32 deals with the Right to Constitutional Remedies, granting citizens the right to approach the Supreme Court for enforcement of fundamental rights. Abolition of Untouchability is covered under Article 17. The other pairs are correctly matched: Article 14 guarantees equality before law, Article 19 provides six freedoms to citizens, and Article 21 protects life and personal liberty.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Central Vigilance Commission: 1. It is a constitutional body 2. Its members are appointed by the President 3. It submits its report to the Parliament 4. It exercises superintendence over the CBI in corruption cases Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 2 and 4 are correct about the Central Vigilance Commission. Its members are appointed by the President based on recommendations of a committee; and it exercises superintendence over the CBI regarding corruption cases. Statements 1 and 3 are incorrect: the CVC is a statutory body (established by the CVC Act, 2003, not mentioned in the Constitution), and it submits its reports to the President, not directly to Parliament.

questions.question: The Indian Constitution has been described as 'quasi-federal' by:
questions.explanation: The Indian Constitution has been described as 'quasi-federal' by K.C. Wheare, a prominent constitutional scholar. In his book "Federal Government," he characterized India's system as "quasi-federal" or "federal with strong unitary features" because it combines federal features (division of powers, bicameralism, independent judiciary) with strong unitary elements (stronger Union government, emergency provisions, Governor's role). This balanced assessment reflects India's unique blend of federal and unitary elements.

questions.question: The 'basic structure doctrine' of the Indian Constitution implies that:

options.text: Parliament cannot amend any part of the Constitution
Certain aspects of the Constitution cannot be amended by Parliament
The Constitution has a federal character

questions.explanation: The 'basic structure doctrine' of the Indian Constitution implies that certain aspects of the Constitution cannot be amended by Parliament. Established in the landmark Kesavananda Bharati case (1973), this judicial doctrine holds that while Parliament can amend any provision of the Constitution under Article 368, it cannot alter or destroy the Constitution's basic structure or essential features like democracy, federalism, secularism, judicial independence, and separation of powers.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Constituent Assembly is NOT correct?

options.text: It was not directly elected by the people
It functioned as the first Parliament of independent India
It completed its task within one year of independence
It had members from different political parties

questions.explanation: The statement "It completed its task within one year of independence" is NOT correct about the Constituent Assembly. The Assembly took nearly three years (2 years, 11 months, and 18 days) to complete the Constitution. It first met on December 9, 1946, and the Constitution was finally adopted on November 26, 1949, coming into effect on January 26, 1950. This lengthy process included extensive deliberations, multiple drafts, and careful consideration of diverse perspectives.

questions.question: The Constitution of India establishes India as a:
questions.explanation: The Constitution of India establishes India as a Quasi-federal State. Though the word "federal" is not used in the Constitution (which describes India as a "Union of States"), the system combines federal features (division of powers, written constitution, bicameralism, independent judiciary) with strong unitary features (stronger Center, emergency provisions, All-India Services). This unique blend led scholars like K.C. Wheare to describe India as "quasi-federal" or "federal with unitary bias."

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Parliamentary privileges in India is correct?

options.text: All privileges are codified in the Constitution
They can be claimed only when Parliament is in session
Courts have no jurisdiction to examine cases of breach of privilege
They include freedom of speech in Parliament

questions.explanation: The statement "They include freedom of speech in Parliament" is correct about Parliamentary privileges in India. Article 105 explicitly guarantees freedom of speech in Parliament, protecting members from legal proceedings for anything said in the House. The other statements are incorrect: parliamentary privileges are not fully codified; they can be claimed even when Parliament is not in session for actions related to parliamentary functions; and courts do have limited jurisdiction to examine privilege cases.

questions.question: Which of the following institutions has the final authority to interpret the Constitution of India?
questions.explanation: The Supreme Court has the final authority to interpret the Constitution of India. As the apex judicial body, the Supreme Court serves as the ultimate interpreter of constitutional provisions through its power of judicial review. Article 141 states that the law declared by the Supreme Court shall be binding on all courts within the territory of India. This authority makes the Supreme Court the final arbiter in constitutional matters.

questions.question: The system of judicial review in the Indian Constitution was borrowed from:
questions.explanation: The system of judicial review in the Indian Constitution was borrowed from the United States of America. While not explicitly mentioned in the US Constitution, judicial review was established in the landmark case Marbury v. Madison (1803). India's Constitution explicitly incorporates this concept through provisions like Articles 13, 32, 131-136, 226, and 246, empowering courts to review legislative and executive actions for constitutional validity.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Governor of a state is NOT correct?

options.text: The Governor is appointed by the President
The Governor holds office during the pleasure of the President
The Governor can promulgate ordinances when the state legislature is not in session
The Governor must belong to the state where he is appointed

questions.explanation: The statement "The Governor must belong to the state where he is appointed" is NOT correct. There is no constitutional requirement that a Governor must belong to the state where appointed; in fact, Governors are typically appointed to states other than their home states to maintain impartiality. The other statements are correct: Governors are appointed by the President, hold office during President's pleasure, and can promulgate ordinances when the state legislature is not in session.

questions.question: Which Article of the Constitution of India provides for the institution of Panchayati Raj?
questions.explanation: Article 40 of the Constitution of India provides for the institution of Panchayati Raj. This article, which is a Directive Principle of State Policy, states: "The State shall take steps to organize village panchayats and endow them with such powers and authority as may be necessary to enable them to function as units of self-government." The 73rd Amendment later added detailed provisions through Articles 243 to 243O.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about writs in the Indian Constitution: 1. Both the Supreme Court and High Courts can issue writs 2. The Supreme Court can issue writs only for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights 3. High Courts can issue writs for the enforcement of Fundamental Rights and for any other purpose 4. The writ jurisdiction of the Supreme Court is wider than that of High Courts Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct about writs in the Indian Constitution. Both Supreme Court and High Courts can issue writs; Supreme Court's writ jurisdiction under Article 32 is limited to enforcement of Fundamental Rights; and High Courts under Article 226 can issue writs for Fundamental Rights and "any other purpose." Statement 4 is incorrect because the High Courts' writ jurisdiction is actually wider than the Supreme Court's, covering both fundamental rights and "any other purpose."

questions.question: Who is authorized to transfer a judge from one High Court to another?

options.text: President in consultation with the Chief Justice of India
President in consultation with the concerned Chief Justices of High Courts

questions.explanation: The President in consultation with the Chief Justice of India is authorized to transfer a judge from one High Court to another. Under Article 222, "The President may, after consultation with the Chief Justice of India, transfer a Judge from one High Court to any other High Court." Following the Three Judges Cases, this power is effectively exercised through the collegium system, with the Chief Justice of India's recommendation being binding on the President.

questions.question: The provisions relating to the suspension of Fundamental Rights during emergencies are not applicable to:

options.text: Right to life and personal liberty (Article 21)

questions.explanation: The provisions relating to the suspension of Fundamental Rights during emergencies are not applicable to rights guaranteed by Articles 20 and 21. Article 359 specifically excludes Articles 20 (protection against double jeopardy, self-incrimination) and 21 (right to life and personal liberty) from suspension during emergencies, following the 44th Amendment. These rights represent core human protections that remain available even during national emergencies.

questions.question: Which of the following Constitutional provisions makes India a secular state?
questions.explanation: Articles 25-28 and 14, 15, 16 collectively make India a secular state. Though the word "secular" was added to the Preamble by the 42nd Amendment, secularism is primarily enshrined through a combination of provisions: Articles 25-28 (religious freedom), Article 14 (equality before law), Articles 15-16 (prohibition of discrimination on religious grounds), Article 27 (freedom from religious taxes), and Article 28 (freedom from religious instruction in state institutions).

questions.question: When can the President of India proclaim financial emergency?

options.text: When there is a threat to the financial stability of India
When there is a threat to the security of India
When any state fails to comply with the directions of the Union Government
When the Parliament passes a resolution requesting for it

questions.explanation: The President of India can proclaim financial emergency when there is a threat to the financial stability of India. Under Article 360, if the President is satisfied that a situation has arisen whereby the financial stability or credit of India or any part thereof is threatened, he can declare a financial emergency. This has never been invoked since independence, even during severe economic crises.

questions.question: Which of the following features of the Indian Constitution was NOT borrowed from the British Constitution?
questions.explanation: Single citizenship was NOT borrowed from the British Constitution. This feature was included as an indigenous innovation to promote national unity and prevent regional parochialism in newly independent India. The other options—parliamentary government, rule of law, and cabinet system—were all inspired by British constitutional practice, reflecting India's experience under British rule and the Westminster system's influence on the constitutional framers.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Contingency Fund of India is correct?

options.text: It is at the disposal of the Union Council of Ministers
It is established under Article 267 of the Constitution
It is a component of the Consolidated Fund of India
It requires parliamentary approval before any withdrawal

questions.explanation: The statement "It is established under Article 267 of the Constitution" is correct about the Contingency Fund of India. Article 267(1) provides for establishing this fund as an imprest placed at the disposal of the President to meet unforeseen expenditures pending authorization from Parliament. The other statements are incorrect: it's at the President's disposal (not Council of Ministers); it's separate from the Consolidated Fund; and it allows expenditure without prior parliamentary approval, though subsequent approval is required.

questions.question: Who has the power to establish Inter-State Councils?
questions.explanation: The President has the power to establish Inter-State Councils. Under Article 263 of the Constitution, "If at any time it appears to the President that the public interests would be served by the establishment of a Council," he may establish such a council. The President determines its duties, organization, and procedure. The Inter-State Council was established in 1990 following recommendations of the Sarkaria Commission on Centre-State relations.

questions.question: Which of the following schedules of the Constitution of India deals with the languages?
questions.explanation: The Eighth Schedule of the Constitution of India deals with the languages. It lists the official languages recognized by the Constitution. Initially starting with 14 languages, the Eighth Schedule has been amended several times and now recognizes 22 languages: Assamese, Bengali, Bodo, Dogri, Gujarati, Hindi, Kannada, Kashmiri, Konkani, Maithili, Malayalam, Manipuri, Marathi, Nepali, Oriya, Punjabi, Sanskrit, Santhali, Sindhi, Tamil, Telugu, and Urdu.

questions.question: The concept of 'Procedure Established by Law' in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from:
questions.explanation: The concept of 'Procedure Established by Law' in Article 21 of the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from the Japanese Constitution. The phrase, which requires that any deprivation of life or personal liberty must be according to procedure established by valid law, contrasts with the American "due process of law" which examines the substantive fairness of law. Over time, however, the Supreme Court has interpreted Article 21 to include elements of substantive due process.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Rajya Sabha: 1. It is a permanent House that cannot be dissolved 2. Its maximum strength is 250 members 3. 12 members are nominated by the President 4. It can initiate constitutional amendments Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: All statements (1, 2, 3, and 4) are correct about the Rajya Sabha. It is a permanent House never subject to dissolution; its maximum strength is 250 (currently 245 members); the President nominates 12 members with special knowledge in literature, science, art and social service; and it can initiate constitutional amendments, which must then be passed by special majority in both Houses (unlike Money Bills that can only originate in Lok Sabha).

questions.question: The 'Ninth Schedule' was added to the Constitution of India by:
questions.explanation: The 'Ninth Schedule' was added to the Constitution of India by the First Amendment Act, 1951. This schedule was created to place land reform laws beyond judicial review, even if they violated fundamental rights. The First Amendment added 13 laws to this schedule; subsequent amendments have expanded it significantly. The Supreme Court in I.R. Coelho case (2007) ruled that laws placed in the Ninth Schedule after April 24, 1973 are subject to judicial review if they violate the basic structure.

questions.question: The scheme of the Constitution of India was mainly inspired by the system obtaining in:
questions.explanation: The scheme of the Constitution of India was mainly inspired by the system obtaining in the United Kingdom. While India borrowed specific provisions from various constitutions, the overall parliamentary democratic system with a cabinet form of government was adopted from the British Westminster model. This includes features like collective responsibility of the executive to the legislature, nominal head of state with a powerful prime minister, and fusion (rather than separation) of executive and legislative powers.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Union Territories is NOT correct?

options.text: They are directly administered by the Central Government
All Union Territories have their own legislatures
The President appoints an administrator or Lieutenant Governor for each UT
Parliament can make laws on any subject in the Union Territories

questions.explanation: The statement "All Union Territories have their own legislatures" is NOT correct about the Union Territories. Only three UTs have legislatures: Delhi, Puducherry, and Jammu and Kashmir (after reorganization in 2019). The other UTs—Ladakh, Chandigarh, Dadra and Nagar Haveli and Daman and Diu, Lakshadweep, and Andaman and Nicobar Islands—do not have legislatures and are directly governed by administrators appointed by the President.

questions.question: Article 1 of the Constitution of India describes India as:

options.text: A Federal State with Unitary features
A Unitary State with Federal features

questions.explanation: Article 1 of the Constitution of India describes India as "a Union of States." The term "Union" was deliberately chosen over "Federation" to emphasize the indestructible nature of the Indian Union. As Dr. B.R. Ambedkar explained during Constituent Assembly debates, "The Federation is a Union because it is indestructible. Though the country and the people may be divided into different states for convenience of administration, the country is one integral whole."

questions.question: The Fundamental Rights in the Indian Constitution are contained in:
questions.explanation: The Fundamental Rights in the Indian Constitution are contained in Part III. Articles 12 to 35 in this part enumerate various fundamental rights, including the right to equality (Articles 14-18), freedom (Articles 19-22), against exploitation (Articles 23-24), freedom of religion (Articles 25-28), cultural and educational rights (Articles 29-30), and constitutional remedies (Articles 32-35). These rights are justiciable and can be enforced through courts.

questions.question: The power to increase the number of judges in the Supreme Court rests with:
questions.explanation: The power to increase the number of judges in the Supreme Court rests with Parliament. Article 124(1) of the Constitution initially provided for 7 judges (1 Chief Justice and 6 other judges) but empowered Parliament to increase this number by law. Parliament has exercised this power several times through amendments to the Supreme Court (Number of Judges) Act, 1956, gradually increasing the strength from the original 8 to the current 34 (including the Chief Justice).

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Financial Emergency under Article 360 is NOT correct?

options.text: It requires parliamentary approval within two months of declaration
During this emergency, the President can reduce the salaries of Supreme Court judges
It has been proclaimed once in India since independence
It can direct a state to observe certain canons of financial propriety

questions.explanation: The statement "It has been proclaimed once in India since independence" is NOT correct about Financial Emergency under Article 360. Financial Emergency has NEVER been proclaimed in India since independence, despite several economic challenges. The other statements are correct: it requires parliamentary approval within two months; the President can direct reduction in salaries of all officials including judges; and states can be directed to observe financial propriety during such emergency.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Central Information Commission: 1. It is a constitutional body 2. It was established under the Right to Information Act, 2005 3. It consists of a Chief Information Commissioner and not more than 10 Information Commissioners 4. Its decisions are binding Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 2, 3, and 4 are correct about the Central Information Commission. It was established under the RTI Act, 2005; consists of a Chief Information Commissioner and up to 10 Information Commissioners; and its decisions are binding, though appealable to High Courts/Supreme Court. Statement 1 is incorrect as CIC is a statutory body created by legislation, not mentioned in the Constitution, unlike constitutional bodies like Election Commission or UPSC.

questions.question: In which of the following cases did the Supreme Court hold that the amendment to the Constitution must not violate its 'basic structure'?

options.text: Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala
Minerva Mills v. Union of India
I.R. Coelho v. State of Tamil Nadu

questions.explanation: In Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala (1973), the Supreme Court held that the amendment to the Constitution must not violate its 'basic structure.' This landmark judgment by a 13-judge bench (7:6 majority) established that while Parliament has the power to amend any part of the Constitution under Article 368, it cannot alter or destroy the Constitution's "basic structure" or "basic features." This doctrine has since served as a limitation on Parliament's amending powers.

questions.question: Which of the following provides for the 'Uniform Civil Code' in India?
questions.explanation: The Directive Principles of State Policy provides for the 'Uniform Civil Code' in India. Article 44, which is a Directive Principle (and therefore non-justiciable), states: "The State shall endeavour to secure for the citizens a uniform civil code throughout the territory of India." This principle aims to replace personal laws based on religious practices with a common set of rules governing matters like marriage, divorce, inheritance, and adoption.

questions.question: The Speaker of the Lok Sabha can resign by addressing his resignation to:

options.text: The Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha

questions.explanation: The Speaker of the Lok Sabha can resign by addressing his resignation to the Deputy Speaker of Lok Sabha. Under Article 94, "A member holding office as Speaker or Deputy Speaker of the House of the People may at any time, by writing under his hand addressed, if such member is the Speaker, to the Deputy Speaker, and if such member is the Deputy Speaker, to the Speaker, resign his office."

questions.question: Which amendment to the Constitution inserted the famous words 'socialist' and 'secular' in the Preamble?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Amendment to the Constitution, enacted in 1976 during the Emergency period, inserted the famous words 'socialist' and 'secular' in the Preamble. This amendment, often called a "mini-Constitution" due to its extensive changes, modified the Preamble from "Sovereign Democratic Republic" to "Sovereign Socialist Secular Democratic Republic" and also added the words "unity and integrity of the Nation" (replacing "unity of the Nation").

questions.question: The concept of 'Directive Principles of State Policy' has been borrowed from the Constitution of:
questions.explanation: The concept of 'Directive Principles of State Policy' has been borrowed from the Constitution of Ireland of 1937. The Irish Constitution contained "Directive Principles of Social Policy" which were non-justiciable guidelines for governance. The Indian Constitution adapted this concept, expanding it to include economic, social, and political principles in Articles 36-51 as goals for the state to achieve, while keeping them non-enforceable in courts.

questions.question: Which one of the following constitutional amendments made education a Fundamental Right?
questions.explanation: The 86th Constitutional Amendment Act, 2002 made education a Fundamental Right. This amendment inserted Article 21A into the Constitution, making education for children aged 6-14 years a fundamental right. It also amended Article 45 (to provide for early childhood care and education for children below 6 years) and added a new fundamental duty under Article 51A(k) for parents/guardians to provide education to their children.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the 'Question Hour' in Parliament: 1. It is mentioned in the Constitution of India 2. It is the first hour of every parliamentary sitting 3. Only ministers can ask questions during this hour 4. It is an important device for parliamentary control over executive Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 2 and 4 are correct about the 'Question Hour' in Parliament. It is the first hour of every parliamentary sitting; and it's an important device for parliamentary control over the executive through questions that Ministers must answer. Statements 1 and 3 are incorrect: Question Hour is a parliamentary convention not mentioned in the Constitution; and only members (not ministers) can ask questions during this time, which ministers must answer.

questions.question: The pardoning power of the President under Article 72 of the Constitution:

options.text: Cannot be questioned in any court of law
Can be questioned in the Supreme Court on grounds of mala fide intent
Can be exercised by the President without the advice of the Council of Ministers
Can be exercised for offenses against military law

questions.explanation: The pardoning power of the President under Article 72 of the Constitution can be questioned in the Supreme Court on grounds of mala fide intent. While this power is broad, the Supreme Court in Epuru Sudhakar case (2006) held that it is subject to judicial review limited to examining whether the decision was taken arbitrarily, with malafides, or based on irrelevant considerations. The power must be exercised on Council of Ministers' advice and includes military law offenses.

questions.question: The judges of the Supreme Court are appointed by:

options.text: The President in consultation with the Chief Justice of India
The President in consultation with the Prime Minister
The President in consultation with the Collegium

questions.explanation: The judges of the Supreme Court are appointed by the President in consultation with the Collegium. While Article 124 provides that the President appoints judges in consultation with the Chief Justice of India and other judges, the Supreme Court in the Three Judges Cases developed the Collegium system, where appointments are made based on the recommendation of a collegium consisting of the Chief Justice and four senior-most judges of the Supreme Court.

questions.question: The concept of 'Judicial Review' in the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from:
questions.explanation: The concept of 'Judicial Review' in the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from the United States of America. While not explicitly mentioned in the US Constitution, judicial review was established in the landmark case Marbury v. Madison (1803). India's Constitution explicitly incorporates this concept through provisions like Articles 13, 32, 131-136, 226, and 246, empowering courts to review legislative and executive actions for constitutional validity.

questions.question: The concept of 'Rule of Law' in the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from:
questions.explanation: The concept of 'Rule of Law' in the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from the United Kingdom. This principle, advocated by A.V. Dicey in his "Introduction to the Study of the Law of the Constitution," holds that no person is above the law, all persons are equal before the law, legal rights must be determined by ordinary courts, and there should be no arbitrariness in government action. Article 14 (equality before law) embodies this concept in India.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the National Human Rights Commission: 1. It is a constitutional body 2. Its chairperson must be a retired Chief Justice of India 3. It has the power to award compensation to victims 4. It can take suo moto cognizance of human rights violations Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 2, 3, and 4 are correct about the National Human Rights Commission. Its chairperson must be a retired Chief Justice of India; it can recommend compensation to victims; and it can take suo moto cognizance of human rights violations. Statement 1 is incorrect as NHRC is a statutory body established under the Protection of Human Rights Act, 1993, not a constitutional body directly created by the Constitution.

questions.question: Which one of the following is NOT a salient feature of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: Rigid procedure for amendment is NOT a salient feature of the Indian Constitution. Unlike truly rigid constitutions that require elaborate processes for amendment, India's Constitution is partly rigid and partly flexible, with many provisions amendable by simple or special majority of Parliament without state ratification. The other options are all salient features: parliamentary system of government (based on Westminster model), independent judiciary with power of judicial review, and federal structure with stronger center.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a way in which a person can lose his Indian citizenship under the Citizenship Act?

options.text: By residence in a foreign country for seven years
By naturalization in a foreign country

questions.explanation: By residence in a foreign country for seven years is NOT a way in which a person can lose Indian citizenship under the Citizenship Act. The Act provides for loss of citizenship through: voluntary renunciation by a citizen of full age; deprivation (cancellation by government for fraud, disloyalty, etc.); and termination (automatic loss upon voluntarily acquiring citizenship of another country). Mere residence abroad, regardless of duration, doesn't result in loss of Indian citizenship.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Attorney General of India is correct?

options.text: He is a member of the Parliament
He is a member of the Union Cabinet
He has the right to speak and take part in the proceedings of both Houses of Parliament
He is appointed by the Chief Justice of India

questions.explanation: The statement "He has the right to speak and take part in the proceedings of both Houses of Parliament" is correct about the Attorney General of India. Under Article 88, the Attorney General has the right to speak and take part in proceedings of either House, any joint sitting, and any parliamentary committee, though without voting rights. The other statements are incorrect: he is neither a member of Parliament nor Cabinet, and is appointed by the President, not the Chief Justice.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Constituent Assembly: 1. It was established under the provisions of the Indian Independence Act, 1947 2. Its members were elected on the basis of universal adult franchise 3. The Objectives Resolution was moved by Jawaharlal Nehru 4. Dr. Rajendra Prasad was its President Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 3 and 4 are correct about the Constituent Assembly. Nehru moved the Objectives Resolution on December 13, 1946, outlining the philosophy of the Constitution; and Dr. Rajendra Prasad served as its President. Statements 1 and 2 are incorrect: the Assembly was established under the Cabinet Mission Plan, 1946 (not the Independence Act); and its members were indirectly elected by provincial assemblies based on limited franchise, not universal adult franchise.

questions.question: The State Election Commissioners are appointed by:

options.text: The Chief Minister of the State

questions.explanation: The State Election Commissioners are appointed by the Governor of the State. Under Article 243K(1), "The superintendence, direction and control of the preparation of electoral rolls for, and the conduct of, all elections to the Panchayats shall be vested in a State Election Commission consisting of a State Election Commissioner to be appointed by the Governor." The State Election Commissioner conducts elections to local bodies like Panchayats and Municipalities.

questions.question: Which of the following is a consequence of judicial review in India?

options.text: The judiciary becomes the most powerful branch

questions.explanation: The Constitution becomes legally supreme is a consequence of judicial review in India. Judicial review establishes constitutional supremacy by empowering courts to invalidate laws that violate constitutional provisions. While this does limit parliamentary sovereignty in some ways, it doesn't make judiciary the most powerful branch—it merely enforces constitutional limitations. The Indian system balances powers through checks and balances while maintaining the Constitution as the supreme law.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a federal feature of the Indian Constitution?

options.text: Division of powers between Centre and States

questions.explanation: Integrated judiciary is NOT a federal feature of the Indian Constitution but rather a unitary feature. Unlike federal countries like the US with separate federal and state judiciaries, India has a single integrated judicial system with the Supreme Court at the apex and High Courts and subordinate courts below it. The other options—division of powers, written constitution, and bicameralism—are all federal features incorporated in India's constitution.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Fundamental Rights is NOT correct?

options.text: They are absolute and cannot be restricted
They are guaranteed against arbitrary state action
Some of them are available only to citizens while others are available to all persons

questions.explanation: The statement "They are absolute and cannot be restricted" is NOT correct about Fundamental Rights. Fundamental Rights in the Indian Constitution are not absolute and can be subject to reasonable restrictions. For example, Article 19 provides for six freedoms but also specifies grounds on which the state can impose reasonable restrictions. Similarly, other rights have built-in limitations or can be restricted during emergencies under Articles 352, 358, and 359.

questions.question: The 'Residuary Powers' under the Indian Constitution are vested with:
questions.explanation: The 'Residuary Powers' under the Indian Constitution are vested with the Parliament. Article 248 and Entry 97 of the Union List (List I) in the Seventh Schedule vest the residuary powers (power to legislate on subjects not enumerated in any of the three lists) in the Parliament. This is a unitary feature of India's federal system, contrasting with federations like the USA where residuary powers are with the states.

questions.question: Under which Article of the Constitution can the President refer a matter to the Supreme Court for its opinion?
questions.explanation: Under Article 143 of the Constitution, the President can refer a matter to the Supreme Court for its opinion. This provision, known as the advisory jurisdiction of the Supreme Court, allows the President to seek the Court's opinion on questions of law or fact that have arisen or are likely to arise and are of such public importance that it is expedient to obtain the Court's opinion. The Court may, after such hearing as it thinks fit, report its opinion to the President.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the pardoning power of the Governor is correct?

options.text: The Governor can pardon death sentences
The Governor can grant pardon for offenses against military law
The Governor can grant pardon for all offenses against state laws
The Governor cannot grant pardons, only suspensions, remissions, etc.

questions.explanation: The statement "The Governor can grant pardon for all offenses against state laws" is correct about the pardoning power of the Governor. Under Article 161, the Governor has the power to grant pardons, reprieves, respites or remissions of punishment, or suspend, remit or commute sentences of persons convicted of offenses against laws relating to matters to which the executive power of the state extends.

questions.question: Which of the following provisions of the Constitution of India cannot be amended by a simple majority in Parliament?

options.text: Change in the name of a state
Change in the boundaries of states
Abolition of the Legislative Council in a state
The directive principles of state policy

questions.explanation: The directive principles of state policy cannot be amended by a simple majority in Parliament. Amendments to the Directive Principles (Part IV) require the special procedure under Article 368 with a two-thirds majority of members present and voting and a majority of the total membership of each House. The other options—changing state names, altering state boundaries, and abolishing Legislative Councils—can all be done by simple majority under Articles 3, 4, and 169.

questions.question: The Preamble to the Constitution of India enshrines:

options.text: Values and ideals of the Constitution

questions.explanation: The Preamble to the Constitution of India enshrines values and ideals of the Constitution. It declares India as a "Sovereign Socialist Secular Democratic Republic" and resolves to secure justice, liberty, equality, and fraternity for all citizens. The Preamble serves as a key to understanding the Constitution's basic structure, reflecting the document's philosophy and fundamental objectives, though it doesn't contain specific rights, duties, or directive principles.

questions.question: The Parliament of India consists of:

options.text: President, Lok Sabha, and Rajya Sabha

questions.explanation: The Parliament of India consists of the President, Lok Sabha, and Rajya Sabha. Article 79 of the Constitution states: "There shall be a Parliament for the Union which shall consist of the President and two Houses to be known respectively as the Council of States and the House of the People." The President is an integral part of Parliament, though not a member of either House, and performs important functions like summoning, proroguing, and dissolving the Lok Sabha.

questions.question: Which of the following states has the highest number of seats in the Lok Sabha?
questions.explanation: Maharashtra has the highest number of seats in the Lok Sabha AFTER Uttar Pradesh. While Uttar Pradesh has the maximum with 80 seats, Maharashtra ranks second with 48 seats, followed by West Bengal and Tamil Nadu with 42 seats each. Madhya Pradesh has 29 seats. This distribution is based on the 1971 Census, as seat allocations have been frozen until after the 2026 Census.

questions.question: Consider the following statements about the Rajya Sabha: 1. It is a permanent House 2. One-third of its members retire every two years 3. It cannot be dissolved 4. Its members are directly elected by the people Which statements are correct?
questions.explanation: Statements 1, 2, and 3 are correct about the Rajya Sabha. It is a permanent House; one-third of its members retire every two years; and it cannot be dissolved. Statement 4 is incorrect because Rajya Sabha members are indirectly elected by the elected members of State Legislative Assemblies through proportional representation by single transferable vote, except for 12 members who are nominated by the President. They are not directly elected by the people.

questions.question: The Indian Constitution was adopted on:
questions.explanation: The Indian Constitution was adopted on 26 November 1949. On this date, the Constituent Assembly formally adopted the Constitution with its 395 articles, 8 schedules, and approximately 145,000 words. After adoption, the Constitution went through legal scrutiny and translation, and eventually came into effect on January 26, 1950, which is celebrated as Republic Day in India. The date August 15, 1947 marks India's independence from British rule.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Comptroller and Auditor General (CAG) of India is NOT correct?

options.text: CAG is appointed by the President
CAG can be removed only through impeachment
CAG can audit both Union and State governments
CAG is eligible for any other office under the Government of India after retirement

questions.explanation: The statement "CAG is eligible for any other office under the Government of India after retirement" is NOT correct. Under Article 148(4), the Comptroller and Auditor General shall not be eligible for further office either under the Government of India or under the Government of any State after he has ceased to hold his office. This restriction ensures independence and prevents potential conflicts of interest arising from post-retirement appointments.

questions.question: Which of the following provides for a bicameral legislature in some states?
questions.explanation: Article 169 of the Constitution provides for a bicameral legislature in some states. This article empowers Parliament to abolish a state's Legislative Council or create one if the Legislative Assembly passes a resolution to that effect by a special majority. Currently, six states have bicameral legislatures: Andhra Pradesh, Bihar, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Telangana, and Uttar Pradesh. The others have unicameral legislatures with only a Legislative Assembly.

questions.question: The first meeting of the Constituent Assembly of India was held on:
questions.explanation: The first meeting of the Constituent Assembly of India was held on 9 December 1946. The inaugural session was presided over by Dr. Sachchidananda Sinha, the oldest member, as the temporary Chairman. Later, on December 11, 1946, Dr. Rajendra Prasad was elected as the permanent Chairman (President) of the Constituent Assembly. The Assembly continued its work for almost three years before adopting the final draft of the Constitution on November 26, 1949.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about Fundamental Duties is correct?

options.text: They were added to the Constitution by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976
They include the duty to pay taxes honestly
They precede the Fundamental Rights in the Constitution

questions.explanation: The statement "They were added to the Constitution by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976" is correct about Fundamental Duties. This amendment, enacted during the Emergency period, added a new Part IVA with Article 51A listing 10 Fundamental Duties of citizens. The other statements are incorrect: Fundamental Duties are not enforceable in courts; they don't include paying taxes (though such a duty was recommended); and they appear in Part IVA, after Fundamental Rights (Part III) and Directive Principles (Part IV).

questions.question: The power to promulgate ordinances when Parliament is not in session is vested with:
questions.explanation: The power to promulgate ordinances when Parliament is not in session is vested with the President. Under Article 123, "If at any time, except when both Houses of Parliament are in session, the President is satisfied that circumstances exist which render it necessary for him to take immediate action, he may promulgate such Ordinances as the circumstances appear to him to require." These ordinances have the same force as Acts of Parliament but must be approved by Parliament within six weeks of reassembly.

questions.question: Which Constitutional Amendment extended the term of Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies from 5 to 6 years (later restored to 5 years)?
questions.explanation: The 42nd Constitutional Amendment, 1976 extended the term of Lok Sabha and State Legislative Assemblies from 5 to 6 years. This amendment, passed during the Emergency period, made widespread changes to the Constitution. However, the 44th Amendment Act, 1978 (passed after the Emergency) restored the original 5-year term for these legislative bodies. The extension to 6 years was widely seen as an attempt to delay elections during the controversial Emergency period.

questions.question: The concept of 'concurrent list' in the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from:
questions.explanation: The concept of 'concurrent list' in the Indian Constitution has been borrowed from the Australian Constitution. The Australian Constitution pioneers the concept of concurrent powers through a specific list where both federal and state governments can legislate. While the Government of India Act, 1935 directly preceded India's Constitution and included a similar three-list system, the original concept was adapted from the Australian model.

questions.question: The members of the Constituent Assembly were:
questions.explanation: The members of the Constituent Assembly were elected by the provincial assemblies. Under the Cabinet Mission Plan of 1946, members were elected indirectly by the members of the Provincial Legislative Assemblies through single transferable vote system of proportional representation. The total membership was to be 389, with 296 from British Indian Provinces and 93 from Princely States, though after partition the assembly had 299 members.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Consolidated Fund of India is correct?

options.text: It is established under Article 266 of the Constitution
It requires parliamentary authorization for withdrawing money
It includes the Contingency Fund of India
It is operated by the Finance Minister

questions.explanation: The statement "It requires parliamentary authorization for withdrawing money" is correct about the Consolidated Fund of India. Under Article 266, no money can be withdrawn from this fund except under appropriation made by law passed by Parliament. The other statements are incorrect: though established under Article 266, it doesn't include the Contingency Fund (a separate fund under Article 267), and it's not operated by the Finance Minister but by the executive with parliamentary oversight.

questions.question: The provision of 'Anti-defection law' is contained in which of the following schedules of the Constitution?
questions.explanation: The provision of 'Anti-defection law' is contained in the Tenth Schedule of the Constitution. Added by the 52nd Amendment Act in 1985, this schedule contains provisions for disqualification of elected members of Parliament and State Legislatures on grounds of defection (switching political parties after election). It specifies conditions when a member may be disqualified, exceptions to disqualification, and establishes the Speaker/Chairman of the House as the decision-making authority in such cases.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a source of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: The Malaysian Constitution is NOT a source of the Indian Constitution. Malaysia gained independence in 1957, after India's Constitution was already in effect. The other options—Government of India Act, 1935 (administrative framework, federal scheme), Irish Constitution (Directive Principles), and Australian Constitution (concurrent list)—were all important sources that influenced various aspects of India's constitutional framework drafted between 1946 and 1949.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT a unitary feature of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: Independent Judiciary is NOT a unitary feature of the Indian Constitution but a federal feature. An independent judiciary with power to interpret the constitution and resolve disputes between different levels of government is a characteristic feature of federal systems. The other options—Single Constitution for the Union and States, All-India Services serving both Union and States, and Emergency Provisions allowing centralization of power—are all unitary features of India's constitution.

questions.question: Who acted as the Constitutional advisor to the Constituent Assembly of India?
questions.explanation: Sir B.N. Rau acted as the Constitutional advisor to the Constituent Assembly of India. As the Constitutional Advisor, he prepared an initial draft based on research and comparative study of various constitutions. His scholarly inputs and expertise significantly influenced the constitutional framework. Dr. B.R. Ambedkar served as the Chairman of the Drafting Committee, while Sir Alladi Krishnaswami Ayyar and N. Gopalaswami Ayyangar were members of this committee.

questions.question: Which of the following relates to the 'Rule of Law' in India?
questions.explanation: Article 14 relates to the 'Rule of Law' in India. This article, which states "The State shall not deny to any person equality before the law or the equal protection of the laws within the territory of India," embodies the principle of rule of law by guaranteeing equality before law and equal protection of laws to all persons. It ensures that no person is above the law and that laws are applied equally without arbitrariness.

questions.question: The Joint Sitting of the two Houses of the Indian Parliament is called by:
questions.explanation: The Joint Sitting of the two Houses of the Indian Parliament is called by the President of India. Under Article 108, when a deadlock occurs between the two Houses over a bill (except Money Bills and Constitutional Amendment Bills), the President can summon them to meet in a joint sitting for resolving the deadlock. The Speaker of the Lok Sabha presides over such joint sittings, but the summoning power rests with the President.

questions.question: The Constitution of India classifies the ministers of the Union Government as:

options.text: Cabinet Ministers, Ministers of State, and Deputy Ministers
Ministers of Cabinet rank, State rank, and Deputy Ministers
Cabinet Ministers, State Ministers, and Parliamentary Secretaries

questions.explanation: The Constitution of India classifies the ministers of the Union Government as Cabinet Ministers, Ministers of State, and Deputy Ministers. While the Constitution does not explicitly classify ministers, Article 75 provides for "a Council of Ministers with the Prime Minister at the head to aid and advise the President." In practice, the Council is hierarchically organized with Cabinet Ministers (highest rank), Ministers of State (second rank), and Deputy Ministers (lowest rank, rarely appointed now).

questions.question: Which of the following Articles provides for the establishment of Administrative Tribunals?
questions.explanation: Article 323A provides for the establishment of Administrative Tribunals. It was added by the 42nd Amendment Act, 1976 and empowers Parliament to establish tribunals for adjudication or trial of disputes and complaints regarding recruitment and conditions of service of persons appointed to public services. This Article led to the enactment of the Administrative Tribunals Act, 1985, which established the Central Administrative Tribunal and State Administrative Tribunals.

questions.question: Under which Article of the Constitution can a Money Bill be introduced only in the Lok Sabha?
questions.explanation: Under Article 117 of the Constitution, a Money Bill can be introduced only in the Lok Sabha. Article 117(1) states that a bill which makes provision for any of the matters specified in Article 110(1) (which defines Money Bills) shall not be introduced in the Council of States (Rajya Sabha). Article 110 defines what constitutes a Money Bill, while Article 109 deals with the procedure regarding Money Bills in the Rajya Sabha.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Lok Sabha Speaker is NOT correct?

options.text: The Speaker votes only in case of a tie
The Speaker presides over joint sittings of both Houses of Parliament
The Speaker decides disqualification of members under the Anti-Defection Law

questions.explanation: The statement "The Speaker votes only in case of a tie" is NOT correct about the Lok Sabha Speaker. While the Speaker normally does not vote on matters before the House, in case of a tie, the Speaker must cast a vote, known as the "casting vote," which is typically exercised to maintain the status quo. The other statements are correct: the Speaker presides over joint sittings, certifies Money Bills, and decides disqualification cases under the Tenth Schedule.

questions.question: Who among the following had proposed the Objective Resolution which later became the basis of the Preamble of the Indian Constitution?
questions.explanation: Jawaharlal Nehru had proposed the Objective Resolution which later became the basis of the Preamble of the Indian Constitution. He moved this resolution in the Constituent Assembly on December 13, 1946, which was unanimously adopted on January 22, 1947. The resolution outlined the objectives and philosophy of the Constitution and provided the framework for the Preamble, often described as the "soul of the Constitution" reflecting its basic structure and fundamental values.

questions.question: The primary objective of establishing the Finance Commission under Article 280 of the Constitution is to:

options.text: Distribute tax revenues between Centre and States
Review the financial position of States

questions.explanation: The primary objective of establishing the Finance Commission under Article 280 of the Constitution is to distribute tax revenues between Centre and States. This constitutional body makes recommendations on vertical devolution (between Union and States) and horizontal devolution (among different States), determines principles governing grants-in-aid to States, and suggests measures to augment State resources. It ensures equitable distribution of financial resources in India's federal system.

questions.question: The President of India is elected by:

options.text: Electoral college with equal representation from all states
Proportional representation through single transferable vote

questions.explanation: The President of India is elected by proportional representation through single transferable vote. Article 55(3) states: "The election of the President shall be held in accordance with the system of proportional representation by means of the single transferable vote and the voting at such election shall be by secret ballot." The election is conducted through an electoral college comprising elected MPs and MLAs with weighted votes based on population.

questions.question: With reference to the Union Executive, which of the following statements is NOT correct?

options.text: The President is elected by an electoral college
The Vice-President acts as the ex-officio Chairman of the Rajya Sabha
The Prime Minister is the head of the Council of Ministers
The President cannot refuse to sign a Money Bill

questions.explanation: The statement "The President cannot refuse to sign a Money Bill" is NOT correct regarding the Union Executive. While Money Bills can only be introduced with the President's recommendation, the President retains the constitutional right to withhold assent to any bill, including Money Bills, though this power is rarely exercised in practice. The other statements are accurate regarding the electoral college for President, Vice-President as Rajya Sabha Chairman, and Prime Minister's role.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Attorney General of India is correct?

options.text: He holds office during the pleasure of the President
He is a member of the Cabinet
He is appointed by the Chief Justice of India
His term of office is five years

questions.explanation: The statement "He holds office during the pleasure of the President" is correct about the Attorney General of India. Under Article 76, the Attorney General is appointed by the President and holds office during the President's pleasure, with no fixed tenure specified in the Constitution. The other statements are incorrect: he is not a Cabinet member, is appointed by the President (not Chief Justice), and has no constitutionally fixed term of office.

questions.question: The concept of 'Concurrent List' in the Indian Constitution gives power to:

options.text: Both Centre and States to legislate on the same subjects
Only Centre to legislate on specific subjects
Only States to legislate on specific subjects

questions.explanation: The concept of 'Concurrent List' in the Indian Constitution gives power to both Centre and States to legislate on the same subjects. The Concurrent List (List III) in the Seventh Schedule contains subjects on which both Parliament and State Legislatures can make laws. In case of conflict between central and state law on a concurrent subject, the central law generally prevails, except in certain circumstances where state law may prevail if it receives presidential assent.

questions.question: The Constitution of India describes India as:
questions.explanation: The Constitution of India describes India as "Bharat, that is India." Article 1 states: "India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States." This dual nomenclature recognizes both the ancient name "Bharat" and the more recent name "India," reflecting the country's historical continuity and diverse heritage. The term "A Union of States" describes India's political structure rather than being the country's name.

questions.question: Who appoints the Chairperson of the Finance Commission?
questions.explanation: The President of India appoints the Chairperson of the Finance Commission. Under Article 280, the President constitutes a Finance Commission every five years (or earlier as needed), which consists of a Chairman and four other members to be appointed by the President. Typically, the chairperson is a person with expertise in public finance, economics, or administration, often a former finance secretary, central bank governor, or economist.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the Union Council of Ministers is NOT correct?

options.text: The Council of Ministers is collectively responsible to the Lok Sabha
The Prime Minister is appointed by the President
The President can dismiss any minister on the advice of the Prime Minister
The total number of ministers cannot exceed 15% of the total membership of the Lok Sabha

questions.explanation: The statement "The President can dismiss any minister on the advice of the Prime Minister" is actually CORRECT about the Union Council of Ministers, so this question has an error. All the statements are correct: the Council is collectively responsible to Lok Sabha; the Prime Minister is appointed by the President; the President can (and does) dismiss ministers on Prime Ministerial advice; and under Article 75(1A), the total number of ministers cannot exceed 15% of Lok Sabha's membership.

questions.question: Which of the following is the guardian of Fundamental Rights in India?
questions.explanation: The Supreme Court is the guardian of Fundamental Rights in India. Article 32 empowers the Supreme Court to issue writs for enforcement of fundamental rights, which Dr. Ambedkar called the "heart and soul" of the Constitution.
